1.description: Many party supplies at pretty darn low prices. New Years selection was pretty good, and if you're having a seasonal party, I've seen this place offer many different things. Overall, one of the larger selections of gear for almost any party you're thinking of.

2.description: In theory, I love Party City. Their site offers a ton of expected and unexpected items for a variety of traditional and obscure occasions...at relatively cheap prices. I'm usually not one for shopping outside of my fortress of solitude (online is aces), but given my tendency for procrastination I occasionally-and unfortunately-find myself in need to make it in person. The site is great, so the store should be too, right?! Wrong. Now, I'm no business genius, but how these guys have 8 dumb@sses wandering around yet they 1.) don't know what they have 2.) don't know where things are 3.) don't give a crap about customers, *and* still stay in business, is beyond me. And when I say 8 people, that's not an exaggeration. I actually had plenty of time to count when I was waiting for one of them to come check me (and the 4 people behind me) out. And, the dumb@sses part may be a generalization, but I tried to get help twice and both times was met with extreme dumb@ssery. Like, seriously. I'm sorry I woke you up from your nap to ask you a question, but we *both* hate being here and uhhh *I'm* not getting paid for it.Moving on...the aisles are also really uncomfortably small, which makes it extra fun when people bring their kids/carts/kids in carts. The clutter that has also been present in the last couple of times I've been there in the aisles does not make shopping any easier either. Also, the last couple trips it's been hot as $hit in there. Ya know when you exhale? And you can feel a disparity with the air outside? Yeah, at Party $hitty, there isn't that.So, there you have it. This place sucks. I like cheap party stuff, but not if I have to trip over things to find it while I sweat my butt off and get ignored by staff. I'll stick with online or perhaps dare try out a different location, but, not this one. Never again.

9.description: I am writing to you to inform you about a recent negative customer experience that I had at one of your Chicago stores.  Store 171: 3417 North Western Ave, Chicago, ILOn Saturday, January 26, 2013, I went to pick up a balloon order for my son's birthday party we were hosting that day.  I arrived early, 7:55am, prior to the store opening so that I could pick up the balloons first thing.  I did notice that there were a couple employees waiting in the parking lot.   I then realized that the store was not scheduled to open until 8:30am.  I left, ran a couple errands, and returned at 8:30am.  I walked to the door and saw that the store was not open but the employees were in the store.   I stood and waited for the store to open.   At about 8:40am another female employee arrived at the store.   The employee, who appeared to be the manager, walked up to the front door, did not speak or acknowledge I was standing at the front door,  shoved herself between me and the door, opened the door with her key and then turned to lock the door making no eye contact with me. She completely ignored my presence. Unfortunately, the rude and inappropriate behavior got worse.I then waited a couple more minutes and one of the other employees pointed out that I was still standing out outside.  The lady who appeared to be the manager came to the door and in a curt manner told me that the store was having system issues.   She did not greet me, offer an apology for me standing in the cold, or offer to let me in the store which should have been opened 15 minutes prior.   She then closed and locked the door again before I had the time to tell her I was there to pick up a balloon order.  I then had to knock on the window to tell  her that I was there to pick up balloons that we had purchased in advance and requested pickup first thing Saturday morning for a late morning party.  She paused for a second and through the locked door asked for my name.  She came back with my balloons and abruptly threw them at me through a half opened door.  They were not in a bag, nor were they weighted.  I asked for a bag and some weights as she was closing and locking the door and again she said something about the system being down.   She walked away.  There was never any courtesy or appropriate conversation offered to me.   I was so taken aback and insulted that I was speechless.I do not know if this issue was caused by the manager being late to open the store, the systems truly being down, or other issues that I am not privy too.   Regardless, I was treated poorly and with a great deal of disrespect. In the past, my family has used your stores around the Chicago area for all of our parties. Right now, I can't say that I will ever visit any of your stores again and certainly will not visit store 171 as long as that individual is working there.  Furthermore, after the events of the day were told to others at the party, as well as, shared on social media you have lost some more customers. I have placed a copy of this letter on the Party City Facebook page and Yelp.   I hope that you and others at your company will see that the rude actions of an employee may have lasting affects in sales and brand loyalty and take the appropriate steps to assure that this type of customer treatment does not happen to other customers.Very Disappointed Customer

18.description: So you need some thing related to a party huh? Hats? Streamers? Sexy adult elf costume? Yes, this place might have the things you are looking for any party you might be throwing, except s/m parties... They have plates, balloons, bags, everything you need and a friendly staff too. Keep an eye on your watch you could be looking around for a while.

10.description: I needed paper plates, napkins, plastic cups - the usual - for my graduation party last weekend.  Having seen the gaudy sign every time I drive by on Western, Party City was the first place that came to mind.They have a parking lot, which is fantastic.  Inside.....it's like.... a plastic rainbow exploded.  They have every imaginable party favor/necessity in every color. The aisles are overflowing.  It's almost a bit overwhelming.After careful deliberation, we settled on some pale blue/dark brown plates and napkins, and some really pretty cocktail napkins.  The designs in the second aisle were surprisingly elegant - I actually got COMPLIMENTS on this stuff!  If you're having a party and want to go a step up from the usual red solo cups, I'd highly recommend this place.  Who knew that disposable dinnerware could be so....attractive?

13.description: Meh.  Seriously.5 negatives:A) Costumes are extremely expensive.  B) Said expensive costumes can be made or created from vintage store materials for at MOST half the price.C) The place is a mad house during Halloween.  I know, you're thinking that this isn't their fault.  Well, it IS their fault for not organizing a way to get the costumes that doesn't involve people chaotically cutting in a half-assed representation of a lineD) I got followed around like I was going to steal stuff.  Maybe I was.  But I couldn't because I was being followed around.E) They were out of hair color spray when I went last week.  It was Halloween pre-week, it should be the week where they are the most stocked!3 positives:A) They have lots of single candy pieces for sell.B) There are some sick faux-weapons for sell.C) They have lots of single candy pieces for sell.5 - 3 = 2 stars.cheeers.

16.description: Aftter all that.....the day of my party I opened up the $10 box of 100 forks, 100 knives and 100 spoons to find: 100 knives200 forks0 spoons

17.description: I like to start my reviews by stating that I ran against more than 1,200 Managers from many different area hotel chains for the Manager of the Year Award - Regional (Chicago) and State (IL) by the IL Dept. of Hotels and Lodging. I won both of those awards, so believe me when I say I know good service or lack thereof when i see it.Service: I called in to say I needed 15 balloons. I was told they can not take phone orders over 12 balloons. This would have been ok if they continued with "However, if you would like to pay with a credit card we can complete your order over the phone, etc. etc." but this did not occur. I was left with no alternatives ( loss of one star ). However, they went on to ask when I would be there and when I said "In 10 to 15 minutes" the young lady on the phone offered to make an exception to the 12 balloon limit for me. One extra star for that customer service.On arrival I saw 2 girls working with two seperate guests at the balloon counter. When I approached with a few others, backup was called for on a wireless headset one employee was equipped with. It appeared she got resistance from the person on the other end of the line so she called for another person to come assist. Moments later, I had two extra people at the counter to assist. At the 20 minute mark (from the time i placed the order over the phone) my first balloon was just now being created or so I thought. When I saw another customer grabbing what I thought was my balloons they told me that is for their order - not mine. I apologized to the other shopper. It was then apparent they put my phone order on hold to assist the 2 customers that were at the counter. If managed properly, they would have called someone from the back to assist with my order before beginning with the guests at the counter and my order would have been ready when I arrived. Lost one star for poor deligation.The price was reasonable and they have just about everything you would need as far as party supplies are concerned. Costumes too, all year round!

15.description: Free, ample parking. Super friendly and helpful staff.  Everything under the moon for a home based caterer looking for everything from cake boxes to fondant to Razzles.  (The Razzles are for me, not my clients!)The only downside to this store - it's always in a bit of disarray.  It seems like they try and do their best to keep it neat and orderly; but it seems as though a small child has always had their grubby little paws all over the thing that I need - that just happens to be the last one in stock.Oh, and avoid it here when Lane Tech lets out in the afternoon.  Western is turned into a parking lot.

0.description: Today was my first visit into Party City.And.. I ventured in today because today is my son Nick's 28thBirthday and I wanted to see what I could find for him.Well.. they have alot of great items for "milestone" birthdayslike 30, 40 and 50 but.. not so much for 28.But.. this store is huge! aisles and aisles of party goods,lotsa halloween costumes, and various other party favors.And.. I did purchase 3 Happy Birthday Balloons for Nick..and they are really nice!I was walking down the street with them and this guy asked me ifI wanted to float away like Mary Poppins!Sounds good to me..And.. I was going to get a little gift bag and fill it with candyfor Nick because it was 15 pieces for $1.00.But.. on the way home I decided to keep the candy for myselfcause I deserve it..For the record.. I paid somewhat more for Nick's Balloonsat Party City than I would have paid at a Dollar Store..But.. thats okay.. the balloons I got were very nice.They had really big character balloons for $9.99 too!I saw a Batman one and I was tempted to get it for myselfbecause Batman is my favorite superhero..Sorry to my Yelp Friend who wears a Superman Costume..:(And.. all of the employees were very nice and helpful.This is a good store, a great stock of merchandise is available.It would be great for parties on a large scale as well.Party City.. I like you..And not just because you have Batman Balloons..:)

5.description: This place has a great variety of party goods. You get inspired just walking through the aisles. I always end up spending more than I intended to. However it can get crazy busy here especially Saturday mornings. Eek! Good luck trying to find an associate that can help you.

11.description: What a sh&t show this place is! Even their parking lot is a crazy mess. Avoid at all costs during any major holiday! Too chaotic for me.

8.description: I'm interrupting my regularly scheduled baking to write a review of this place.I'm participating in the Yelp Bake Sale for Haiti tomorrow, so I came straight home after work to whip up many batches of chocolate chip cookies.My mise-en-place was, well, in place, when I realized I had nothing in which to package my culinary delights. My kitchen already looks like flour exploded all over it, but I had to abandon it to go out and get something attractive to put my treats in, in order to sell for maximum dollar.Enter Party City. I've never been in here before, despite driving by a minimum of 1,000,000 times in my life.I walked in and it looked like Spongebob, Barbie, and Star Wars threw up in here. I was in a hurry, so I found the closest employee and asked him to show me small bags I could put food in. Who knew there were so many choices? There were big bags and little bags, in every color of the rainbow. I quickly settled on small clear bags with a star design. The employee made small talk and asked me what kind of party I was having. I explained the Yelp event and that we were having a bake sale to raise money for Haiti. He was so touched that he gave me all the bags for free. I tried to talk him out of it, but he explained that "it was in the budget to make charitable donations." Whether that's corporate policy or not, I didn't question his benevolence.So thank you, kind employee of Party City. I'm sorry I didn't get your name, but your good deed was appreciated, especially in my rushed and frazzled state.And if you're reading this, please come to our Bake Sale and support this wonderful cause. Here's hoping my cookies are edible and that the event is a huge success.

4.description: The location is a bit odd but it was easy to get to. It's the only party city close to me so I had to venture out a bit. They had many party items. Staff was a bit blah. They weren't very friendly but were informative when I needed help/advice.Balloons + helium are $1. They only last 6-12 hours.

14.description: Party City has a lot of plastic, made in China products for your next cheesy party. It's a fun place to wander around and then end up spending too much money on junk that will end up in a landfill for the next 200 years.  I came here on one spring weekend morning right when they opened so that I could get some balloons. When I went to check out, the man behind the register looked at me like I was insane. I was told it was graduation weekend and it was impossible for me to get balloons. I wondered what the 5-6 empty-handed, bored employees were doing standing behind the counter, or if I could get some pre-filled balloons, but the man at the registered continued to snap at me like I was being rude by actually trying to purchase something. I ended up going to Strack, where they kindly gave me some balloons immediately. Was that so hard?Work on your customer service please.

6.description: 1. Parking Lot.2. Right next to FedEx. 3. Halloween Costumes in July. 4. Mass quantities of multi-colored paper products. (yippy, that makes me so randomly excited) 5. Bachelorette party junk galore. Basically, if you are having ANY type of party...you probably need to stop here. Prices are good, parking lot is convenient.Invitations at FedEx, party shizzzz at Party City=All set. :)

58.description: Tucked away on a quiet corner of the Roscoe Village neighborhood, Four Moon has a great outdoor patio for a few drinks on a low key summer night.  The large beer selection has some unique options, such as the Two Brothers Laughing Panda Green Tea IPA - I couldn't really taste the tea, but I love IPA's.  Our server was quick and attentive to our large group.  Prices are pretty standard for the area.

56.description: "Homey" is a term that gets tossed around a lot in culinary reviews, especially when it comes to Chicago's many local neighborhood taverns.  I've yet to visit any of these places and truly feel the comfort of home, until Four Moon Tavern.  Like Four Moon Tavern, my home was often filled with drunk actors continually topping off their wine and eating plates of potato pierogi late into the night.This is a theater bar, or so I've been told.  Being in the improv scene, you may be surprised how different our haunts are from the stomping grounds of the dramatic actors.  This is an atmosphere that is conducive to conversation.  The music is eclectic, falling on a broad spectrum from Rod Stewart to Miles Davis.The beer selection is fairly comprehensive, whether you're a snob looking to impress (or more likely annoy) your friends with your extensive craft-brew knowledge, to the less discerning drunk who's okay with a High Life.The food is comforting, and as I mentioned before, features some of my childhood staples like pierogi, grilled cheese and tomato soup (highly recommended), and the best no-nonsense burger in Roscoe Village.This place brings me back to a time in my life when I would sit underneath the dining room chairs and listen to my parents and friends share the same stories they always shared.  This time though, if you find me under a chair, it's because I've had too many.

29.description: "Sometimes you wanna go, where everybody knows your name." And if that's the case - head to Four Moons Tavern! This was my go-to neighborhood spot when I lived in Roscoe Village. Between the down to earth, "known you for years" staff, awesome comfort food, and cheap beer...this is a great place to become a "local".At this cozy spot you can relax at a table outside, post up at the bar (like we usually did), or play some pool. The back room is more intimate with tables and a couch and makes for a great date night.I've eaten here a number of times & have tried the quesadilla, marinated chicken gyros sandwich, nachos, char-grilled burger, beer battered fish and chips, classic homemade sloppy Joe, the big salad and their pirogues. While all these selections did not disappoint, my ultimate favorite meal at Four Moons is their Meatloaf Sandwich. This perfected home cooked meatloaf is served on either a roll or toast (your choice) with lettuce, tomato, mayo & fries and oh man... is it out of this world! They also serve brunch on Sundays and although I've never been, but I've heard it's quite spectacular (and probably the perfect hangover cure!).Of course I don't just venture on over to this local tavern for food, we make sure to quench our thirst as well when we're here. They have a full bar along with 11 beers on tap, 41 bottles and 14 different cans. Now that's a selection! Looking to nail down your go-to "spot" on the north side? Four Moons will welcome you with open arms! Plus, they have a food and drink special for every day of the week. Gotta love that!

42.description: I think the owner needs to have his head examined.  The female bartenders are the worst in the city.  They treat customers like crap.  It's not a novelty.  I can't say enough bad things about these bartenders.  They suck.  No one likes them and yet they continue to work there.

23.description: Definitely 5 stars for Four Moon. We were a group of 10 that were visiting for the first time, and we were all very happy with our experience. Everyone from our group was running around from our table, to outside, to the bar and then to the pool table with a lot of separate tabs. Through it all we had the BEST service, and for that I am really grateful. I picked this place on a whim, but because of the awesome service and the neighborhood bar atmosphere -- I know I'll be back -- and the same goes for the two handfuls of friends that I brought along.

47.description: Cool little hidden gem in Roscoe Village. Food is above the average bar food. Great bartenders with reasonable beer prices. Small place with great ambiance.

8.description: There is only one reason I don't give this bar that 5th star, and it's the bathroom. A onesie bathroom in a bar is inexcusable in my eyes. You know people go to the bathroom a lot when they're drinking! Otherwise, I love this place. I've only been a few times, but each time I loved it so much. I don't know the bartenders, it's not my local, and it's not even a regular stop in my life. But it always feels comfortable and welcoming, and I love that.

31.description: Friendly service, but nothing special. A good local place to hang out and get some decent food at a good price.

34.description: Pool Table- CheckCheap Drinks- CheckStrangers who talk to one another- CheckEverything about this place is great. Great place to catch up with all friends, drink on the cheap, play some pool, listen to some tunes and feel at ease.

16.description: Cozy local neighborhood bar with a pool table and great menu.  I have the homemade tomatoe soup and grilled cheese with ham.  Both were very good and fairly large portions of food.  My boyfriend had the mushroom and meat pierogi, which were no different then buying from the store, but really enjoyed their Sunday special- pot roast.  We will definately be back here again.

13.description: I had never been to Four Moon Tavern, but on a bitterly cold Chicago night my best friend and I popped in for a few beers. Suffice to say we got more than we bargained for, a killer beer menu, awesome company and a completely off the hook food menu. The music, clientele and vibe were AWESOME! Best part of all, this place has had the best Golden Marble I've ever had, wanna get knocked on your ass??? Just ask for Nikki, she'll be happy to push. This place rooles, five *****'s.

11.description: I'm sorry Four Moon Tavern. I'm sorry that I have lived so close for 4 years, yet failed to truly appreciate you. I'm sorry that I have eaten there numerous times, yet not appreciated your food. I'm sorry I've taken your good beer selection, friendly bartenders, and jovial neighborhood vibe for granted.Four Moon is a shining gem buried within the confines of the friendly west Lakeview and east Roscoe Village streets of Damen and Lincoln. It is an easy-going, low key bar reflective of the neighborhood it serves. The bar maintains a significantly above average selection of beers relative to it's other neighborhood/corner bar competitors. What makes this place so special is the food. The food isn't fancy or anything special. It is simply regular pub food made from scratch. They use few frozen or processed ingredients. It wasn't until Sunday night when I picked up a burger to go that I realized how amazing the food truly is. The burger was juicy and succulent, topped with my choice of cheddar, and served with fries cut in house. It is one of the most simply satisfying and tasty burgers you can have. You must try the burger!Go for the beer and stay for the food!

39.description: It is what it is, and that's good. :)This place is about as low key as it gets. Expect a cozy, dark, corner bar feel, friendly service, and yummy-in-the-tummy food. During the summer, the patio is packed with friendly neighbors, dogs,  and a fresh, filling breakfast. During the winter, the bar is always crowded with people in their ski gear. It's usually hard to get a seat. People tend to park and stay a while. I recommend any breakfast item, the burgers and fries, and the chili. My friends who like beer enjoy the selection. They don't have the best wine selection, but that's probably what you'd expect for such a laid-back place. You can head to Volo for top notch wine picks.  I almost hate to give this place five stars because I like going here... but what the heck? I've benefitted from other top reviews and haven't been disappointed. So I'm sharing the love. ENJOY!!!

37.description: Nice outdoor seating area , friendly staff, and good beer selection. This is my favorite bar in roscoe village. Everything I have tried on the menu is good.  Only complaint would be that it hasn't been updated in some time.

0.description: This was my first stop when I came to town for the weekend to visit a friend, it was very laid back and we brought an uno deck as we drank and snacked on our food. The service was great and the prices reasonable.But the only reason I thought to write a review is because the employees were nice enough to not throw us out or get upset with us when we accidentally dropped a shot glass and had a beer spill while playing pool, we were not drunk whatsoever and felt bad about breaking the glass but they were not upset.

38.description: One of my favorite neighborhood bars! I've been coming here for years. Always has a great beer list and staff very helpful coming up with great recommendations. Food is great and menu has a nice variety. Still want to try brunch! Only wish there were more tables in the bar area as sometimes it's so crowded and prefer front/outside to the back area.

51.description: BEST CHICKEN TENDERS IN THE CITY!!!!Hands down the best tenders I've had in Chicago. I would love for someone to tell me they know of better because I can't even imagine it...only a mystical unicorn could make better tenders. The breading is super thick and seasoned perfectly, and the chicken is so tender and moist they literally melt in your mouth. Plus their honey mustard dipping sauce is  divine.Service is always great, and they have good drink specials. Pretty much all you can ask for in a good neighborhood bar, and that's exactly what it is, so don't expect anything more. If you do expect more, than you shouldn't be going here because everybody will hate you, especially me!

27.description: Met a friend here for an early dinner and a couple beers on a Tuesday afternoon. When walking up from the brown line I almost walked right by the place. It really feels like a neighborhood bar/pub. It was pretty empty, but that was probably due to being there so early. The weather was nice so we sat outside. Let's see here, beer selection was good though they were out of what I wanted. The bartender was pretty knowledgeable about their beers which is always nice. I had a burger which was quite big and cooked properly. Definitely made from scratch and not a frozen hockey puck. The toppings were fine and the bun was almost a large dinner roll. I liked it. The fries look to be handcut, but are pretty thick and were not crispy. Everything did come out hot and fresh though. Aside from the lackluster fries, I wasn't crazy about the other options on the menu. A Reuben would be an excellent addition I think. (If I missed it I'm sorry! I'll edit the review later). The lady who was working the bar and waited on us was very pleasant and seemed to genuinely care that we were enjoying out visit. I really like places that are true to themselves and fit in well rather than catering to the pretentious hipster crowd. Definitely worth a return trip.

32.description: I'm pretty old.Twelve or fifteen or even twenty years ago I'd have been a bunch more enthused about spending too many hours at a place like Four Moon.  But we don't really go out drinking any more.  Still, I can appreciate from a Sunday evening dinner there that it looks like a great lowlit, timeless barroom, with good music on the sound system, loads of neighborhood tavern atmosphere, and friendly good times.  Hell, if I were going there to drink, I could see it being a five-star kind of place.But we were staying in the neighborhood and read up on neighborhood places to have a somewhat late casual meal, and the reviews of Four Moon Tavern suggested that it had really good pub food as well.  On that score, Four Moon was pretty damn disappointing.  In fact, the meatloaf sandwich I ordered was one of the least appetizing things I've had in a restaurant in a while:  It was more meat-mush or meat-paste than meatloaf, squishing out of the bun when you tried to chomp through it.  Just a complete mess.  And almost flavorless.  Wife's chili was OK, but overly sugary.  Brother-in-law ordered a burger, and that item looked big and worthwhile.  Handcut fries looked better than they tasted, i.e., warmed over for too long.Decent beer selection, and on the night we were there, efficient if rather grumpy service.Four to five stars for the barroom.  But closer to two for our food on this night.  That's not all that great an average.

54.description: Holy shit!!! We wanted Jack Daniels and Nikki the bartender said they had it!  She poured us up two shots (the way they should be poured) and blam!   Best place ever!

48.description: LOVE.I love this spot.  Yes, it's somewhat divey (not too much, but a bit), but the food is excellent, the service is top notch and it's so cute and cozy for a relaxed dinner.I have to say that while I've had burgers here, I think that the chicken sandwich is wonderful.  I don't know what they do to it, but it's delicious and juicy and that bun - wow!!  Great beer specials and the wine is pretty good considering I would put this in the 'beer drinkers bar' category.Service is always really nice here and even if you happen to be the only ones in the back room (as we were once), they do not forget about you.  Score!

44.description: Love this place!  Joe is the bomb-diggity best server ever.  Saturday brunch is fantastic.  Beer selection is ever changing and so delicious.  Don't go changing Four Moons!  We love you!

24.description: Popped in for a mid-evening beverage or two while waiting for a friend to make their way into the city.  Sat at the window at the front and enjoyed the folks drifting by, while having great conversation with the front door guy.  A nice neighborhood spot.

7.description: Just moved into Roscoe Village  and the first few days here did not very unpacked so since this is a block away and i thought I'd try it.  I'm very glad I did staff is great and very friendly. Great food this is my new go to place.

49.description: My hubby and I have a new fav bar to go to. We went here last night to watch the Beavs play. The bar was comfy and had a nice crowd (not very crowded at all - nice and mellow). The bartender was really nice, and the food was good as well. As I am gluten-free I usually am SOL when it comes to bar food, but there were a variety of delicious options for me. Wings were excellent -as were nachos. Well done Four Moon Tavern!

40.description: I have no idea what the bar service is like because I'm not a big drinker and prefer "sit-down at a real table" experiences.  I head straight to the tables in the back room.  Four Moon gets four stars for four reasons:1) Grilled cheese!  You can add all kinds of stuff but I recommend the bacon.  2) Sloppy joes!3) Hummus... no really, the hummus plate is quite good and they include delightful black olives. 4) Fried sides (french fries, sweet potato fries, onion rings) that taste real and aren't too greasy.I've always found the service to be friendly and efficient and when I do order drinks they're good.  It's not fancy so if you're a "foodie" or want trendy decor you are out of luck.  It is consistently good comfort food though.  Four Moon was a go-to hangout when one of my friends was in the Chicago indie theater scene and when she's back in town, we almost always make a trip here.

53.description: Their breakfast is great, try the Harold.Good beer selection too. Terrible makers of old-fashioned's but i won't hold that against them. Really though probably the worst old fashioned these lips have experienced.Good people that run the place

30.description: Walked in and asked the bartender if he wouldn't mind putting on the Packer game. Preseason no less. I knew this was a risky proposition but I forged forward. The bartender was so nice and tried to get the game on with no luck. We settled on the Bears preseason game (reasonable compromise) but I offered him a shot for his troubles and for not laughing me out of the bar at my request. We shared in this fine Chicago tradition together. Bottom line: fun place with great people. Very chill, unpretentious bar. I'll be back.

46.description: If you are looking for a great neighborhood bar with good food and a good drink/beer selection, then stop looking. :) Bartenders absolutely rock here. And in case someone hasn't mentioned the tenders, they are awesome. I like the lasagne as well for some reason. :) Again, a great spot to chill with friends.

1.description: This place is a small, quaint, neighborhood bar that typifies the "regular" crowd. The food is really good, especially the Friday fish and chips special (year round) and the Nachos. Actually, these are some of my favorite nachos in the city because almost every chip is covered with toppings. The small size nachos is perfect for 1-2 people if you want to get a main meal as well - the large comes in a gigantic bowl that can easily serve 4-5. The prices are good and the beers on tap change regularly, which keeps it interesting. They usually have a season Three Floyds and Revolution on tap, sometimes only a few kegs of each, so you have to catch it at the right time. Only con is that it's pretty small and the seating is somewhat cramped in the bar area, though they do have a bigger restaurant seating area in the back if you're looking for a quieter space. I've lived in Roscoe for a few years and I keep coming back!

55.description: I need to start by saying I hate Roscoe Village--okay, I don't hate, I simply dislike.  There seems to be a need for a good go-to place,and Roscoe Village doesn't provide that deep-seeded desire.  Well, at least so I thought.  I came to Four moon for the first time today.  It is brilliantly coy in its presentation, yet unbelievably charming.  The beer selection could rival any bar in the North Side of Chicago, and the food was comforting.  I'm so stoked I found this gem, I can once again be reminded of the oddly comforting moment of not knowing what to eat and having the ability to go to a "safe go-to."Fair Warning:  If you're looking for something trendy and hot, like a flash in the pan, go else where.  This place only offers intellectually stimulating atmosphere, and intentional conversation.

9.description: Love coming to this neighborhood bar when visiting my cousin.  The bartenders are always so much fun, and surprisingly the food is wonderful.  The reason I say surprisingly is because I have never thought much of bar food, but they have daily specials and the food is good.  Large portions too.My favorite bartender is Tosha.

26.description: Dog friendly patio in Roscoe Village with a nice beer selection and decent food. What's not to like?Sat outside on a gorgeous Saturday and was greeted by a VERY enthusiastic waiter. knew this wasn't his full time gig but really appreciated his upbeat spirit. Not too often you get a server who isn't anything more than pleasant. I guess I like dinner and a show.he went thru the beer list and told us what they were out of right off the  bat so there wouldn't be any disappointment. I appreciated that. Wound up with a nice saison I would have never tried / heard of which was delicious.Wife ordered quesadillas and I had a chicken gyro. Both portions were generous and for the price, were a value. Food was decent but nothing that's going to win any culinary awards but hey, solid food and a good price sometimes beats superb food at a ridiculous price!As dogs are allowed on the patio, that was the clincher as while the weather is nice, we are always looking to take out four legged friends with us places. Some patios ask you put your dogs on the "other side of the railing" but not here. They sat nicely under the table and enjoyed the day along with us.Overall a nice neighborhood place that I'd definitely go back to again.

25.description: Love coming to this neighborhood bar when visiting my cousin.  The bartenders are always so much fun, and surprisingly the food is wonderful.  The reason I say surprisingly is because I have never thought much of bar food, but they have daily specials and the food is good.  Large portions too.My favorite bartender is Tosha.

12.description: Stopped here on a whim with my wife the other night.  We were picking up our car from the shop and looking for a place to eat in Roscoe Village, so we turned to our trusty friend Yelp.  Saw some good reviews and decided to give it a shot.  As we neared, saw it from the outside and it looked a bit like a house converted into a bar.  It looked inviting, but I was a little suspicious that I might get the kind of meal there that I was hungry for.  We checked back with Yelp and you good people assuaged me, so we headed in.To borrow a Dutch word, Four Moon Tavern is gezellig.  The atmosphere was great, warm, inviting, and it felt like a hidden gem tucked away on a residential street.  The music selection was some post-punk, and the waitress, Nicki, who took our order was friendly, helpful and made us feel very welcome there.The food was unpretentious, fresh, and fantastic.  We started with an order of crab cakes which were excellent.  It was served on some leafy greens and topped with a delicious creamy red pepper sauce.  We were both impressed from the get-go.  My wife had the grilled cheese which was amazing and I  had the cheeseburger which was juicy and delicious.  The fries were also cooked to perfection and I was salivating from the scent of them in the air long before our meals arrived.  To top it off, they had a very nice beer selection with quite a few beers I hadn't tried before. Bottom line is that Four Moon offers a fantastic meal, good beer, quality service in a unique friendly setting unlike many other bars in Chicago.  I'll be back.

59.description: Great food. Plenty of it and well priced. Our waitress tosha was amazing!!!!! Best hamburger I've had in a long time.

21.description: Cozy local neighborhood bar with a pool table and great menu.  I have the homemade tomatoe soup and grilled cheese with ham.  Both were very good and fairly large portions of food.  My boyfriend had the mushroom and meat pierogi, which were no different then buying from the store, but really enjoyed their Sunday special- pot roast.  We will definately be back here again.

17.description: This place is a neighborhood favorite. Think hopleaf but more casual without sacrificing on taste.  Food's great too. Also the kitchen is open until midnight which is nuts and pretty much puts it up against Burrito House in the neighborhood for late night eats. Which obviously means Four Moon is winning.

10.description: "Sometimes you wanna go, where everybody knows your name." And if that's the case - head to Four Moons Tavern! This was my go-to neighborhood spot when I lived in Roscoe Village. Between the down to earth, "known you for years" staff, awesome comfort food, and cheap beer...this is a great place to become a "local".At this cozy spot you can relax at a table outside, post up at the bar (like we usually did), or play some pool. The back room is more intimate with tables and a couch and makes for a great date night.I've eaten here a number of times & have tried the quesadilla, marinated chicken gyros sandwich, nachos, char-grilled burger, beer battered fish and chips, classic homemade sloppy Joe, the big salad and their pirogues. While all these selections did not disappoint, my ultimate favorite meal at Four Moons is their Meatloaf Sandwich. This perfected home cooked meatloaf is served on either a roll or toast (your choice) with lettuce, tomato, mayo & fries and oh man... is it out of this world! They also serve brunch on Sundays and although I've never been, but I've heard it's quite spectacular (and probably the perfect hangover cure!).Of course I don't just venture on over to this local tavern for food, we make sure to quench our thirst as well when we're here. They have a full bar along with 11 beers on tap, 41 bottles and 14 different cans. Now that's a selection! Looking to nail down your go-to "spot" on the north side? Four Moons will welcome you with open arms! Plus, they have a food and drink special for every day of the week. Gotta love that!

5.description: This is my favorite bar, and my greatest sadness is that I can't go here all the time. The beer is great. The food is even better. Yes, a kinda divey bar with awesome, AWESOME, food. There are few better low-key saturday night date ideas than Four Moon for some drinks and a delicious blackened fish sandwich. Also fish and chips. And, surprisingly, the gyro. And the nachos! My husband loves the nachos.Not to mention the atmosphere in here is just great. Perfect little neighborhood bar-- relatively quiet, friendly and helpful staff, easy parking, and they are always happy to change the tv if you ask. I love this place. And I wish I could have some fish and chips for dinner right now.

3.description: First time here and I really dogged the ambiance of the joint. Nice to have some drinks and chit chat with some friends. They were playing quite the variety of music, which is nice. Service was great! I had a great evening here.

35.description: Still killer bar food, but with an even better beer selection. They added more taps years ago and offer a very nicely rounded selection, with an emphasis on some of the newer and better local breweries. Their beer prices are also great - definitely at least a dollar less than most other places and their monthly $4 special is always solid.

19.description: I've only been a few times. But it's a great local pub. Lots of beer on tap and decent specials. Staff and patrons are always welcoming. Has some nice outdoor seating space in the front.

28.description: Timeless neighborhood tavern, as good as it gets. There aren't many things I really miss about Roscoe Village, but you better believe Four Moon is #1. Used to go on a weekly basis, now it's about once a month. After dozens of times, I can say i've never had a bad time here. Sure, there was the occasional obnoxious patron, or the one time I ordered the meatloaf sandwich, otherwise nothing but good times. The vibe is unique and cozy, with unpretentious patrons who warm up to you after awhile. Lots of eclectic stuff around, original art, themed vintage LP covers above the jukebox, knick-knacks high above the bar stools, and a really nice back bar. Patio is great in the sunny months, and the room inside warms the soul on cold winter nights. The bar staff is fun and cracks jokes, so it's wise to have a sense of humor here. A few uptight reviews here sort of explain themselves. Over the years, they've steadily built a very respectable beer list, and host some fun beer events now and then. Local favorites Half Acre, Spiteful, and Revolution are ever-present in the rotating tap lineup. Lots of good cans, a few imports, always a new seasonal on tap. You can usually find a good chuckle in the pages of the beer list. Always a $4 beer of the month special, always something worth drinking. Interesting handful of whiskeys. I like to bounce between here and Village Tap to change it up. Food wise, the specials are the strong suit (jambalaya, pot roast, chicken & dumplings), but i've got a weakness for the bacon cheddar burger and the Sheboygan bratwurst dinner. Hearty stick your ribs stuff, no frills, just tasty. The spinach salad is pretty awesome, as well as the crab stacks for brunch. The meatloaf sandwich really should be on the kids menu (I only tried it once while making my way through the entire menu one winter). All in all, Four Moon is a stone cold classic.

45.description: Good food, casual atmosphere.  Really quick take out service. Always friendly. The one thing I wish they'd work on... Their fries!  Really awful French fries:( come on! You can do it! Work on those fries!

33.description: I'm surprised Four Moon is 4 stars since they do everything right:  the beer, the service, the food, the atmosphere, the music ... it's all just so perfect for a neighborhood bar.And I see some people on here calling it a dive, and it's not a dive, folks.  It's a neighborhood bar done right.144/365

43.description: The food s nothing to write home about.  The bloody mary's on Saturdays are $4.00 which is nice.  The bar isn't very comfortable (depth wise) so your knees jam into it.  I am 5'5" and was glad to leave because my knees hurt.  There are about 4-5 bar height tables along the wall which would be more comfortable if you can snag one of those.  Service wise was kind of off too, we had an appetizer, but no appetizer plates so we were just using napkins as plates.  I'd probably come back in the summer to sit out on the patio and have a beer but that's about it....also the day we were here, 4 idiots let their children run around in the place, wrestling near the windows and my chair, trying to sit at the bar, and dragging eachother through the restaurant.  Here's a tip:  this is a bar.  Children shouldn't be allowed in a bar, I don't care how bad mom and pops need a cocktail...

2.description: GREAT FOOD, Good Beer, Reasonable Drinks and Friendly people what more do you need for a local watering hole! I love this place and continue to go because of the reasons mentioned above and it's super casual which is nice especially when you don't feel like getting all dolled up ;) FYI: I'm a country girl and love a good meatloaf-the "loaf" at this place isn't too shabby and the fries (googly eyes) soooo damn good...

18.description: I'm pretty old.Twelve or fifteen or even twenty years ago I'd have been a bunch more enthused about spending too many hours at a place like Four Moon.  But we don't really go out drinking any more.  Still, I can appreciate from a Sunday evening dinner there that it looks like a great lowlit, timeless barroom, with good music on the sound system, loads of neighborhood tavern atmosphere, and friendly good times.  Hell, if I were going there to drink, I could see it being a five-star kind of place.But we were staying in the neighborhood and read up on neighborhood places to have a somewhat late casual meal, and the reviews of Four Moon Tavern suggested that it had really good pub food as well.  On that score, Four Moon was pretty damn disappointing.  In fact, the meatloaf sandwich I ordered was one of the least appetizing things I've had in a restaurant in a while:  It was more meat-mush or meat-paste than meatloaf, squishing out of the bun when you tried to chomp through it.  Just a complete mess.  And almost flavorless.  Wife's chili was OK, but overly sugary.  Brother-in-law ordered a burger, and that item looked big and worthwhile.  Handcut fries looked better than they tasted, i.e., warmed over for too long.Decent beer selection, and on the night we were there, efficient if rather grumpy service.Four to five stars for the barroom.  But closer to two for our food on this night.  That's not all that great an average.

41.description: Lovely neighborhood spot. Great beer selection and you will get served from folks who actually know their beers. Check out the daily specials- all the food is fresh. Jambalaya and the pot roast are my favorites. Check it out, you'll be glad you did.

52.description: Nice cozy  little spot ...I had the chicken gyro and it was extremely satisfying. The beer selection is solid as well as  the service . I plan on going back.

50.description: Love this place! It's kind of a hidden gem, as it's not exactly on the main stretch of Roscoe. It's only a few blocks away, though! Great bar food, delicious fries & great service. Love their craft beer selection and they have nice weekly specials. Definitely recommend, if you want to check out a low key and homey dive!

4.description: I reserve this as a suggestion for my toughest, laid-back, no frills customers.  Quirky date?  Yes.  Old friend?  yes.  New friend?  Yes.  Bar crawl?  Yes.  And the little girl's picture on the ladies restroom door looks just like me as a child.  If I were born in the 50s.Great beer list, especially if you like local stuff (bottles and draft), and I noticed they have a bunch of Belgium stuff that I learned on my beer tour in Brussels this summer (abbey, tripel, etc.).  This might sound like a weird recommendation, but it's a hit during Lent for us old school Catholics because of the fish and chips and grilled cheese.Side note:  It also draws an interesting crowd.  I was on a quirky first date with a Russian spa manager (?!), and we got sucked onto a Brown Line bar crawl - that we joined.  This turned into one of my favorite events of last summer.

6.description: Love this place, as I've been coming to it for years!  It's sorta got that Cheers vibe, where everyone knows your name.It's not a place to order a fancy martini, so if that's your gig, I'd recommend going elsewhere.Robbie, the bartender, makes all of the food fresh and you can tell it's seriously homemade.  I recommend smash browns for brunch and big salad (Seinfeld style), perogies, tomato soup, pizza, fish and chips and grilled cheese for grub.Great beers on tap and pretty damn good Bloody Marys (not mix.... Homemade) on Saturday and Sunday brunch are a must!Nikki is a bartender, and she, along with the pool table and sweet juke box tunes make this the perfect dive bar.They've also outdoor seating in the summer and welcome canine pals!

22.description: Super friendly bartender!  Owner?Friendly staff, cozy indoors, summer patio, average food, not many beers and no sours but enough!

15.description: Met a friend here for an early dinner and a couple beers on a Tuesday afternoon. When walking up from the brown line I almost walked right by the place. It really feels like a neighborhood bar/pub. It was pretty empty, but that was probably due to being there so early. The weather was nice so we sat outside. Let's see here, beer selection was good though they were out of what I wanted. The bartender was pretty knowledgeable about their beers which is always nice. I had a burger which was quite big and cooked properly. Definitely made from scratch and not a frozen hockey puck. The toppings were fine and the bun was almost a large dinner roll. I liked it. The fries look to be handcut, but are pretty thick and were not crispy. Everything did come out hot and fresh though. Aside from the lackluster fries, I wasn't crazy about the other options on the menu. A Reuben would be an excellent addition I think. (If I missed it I'm sorry! I'll edit the review later). The lady who was working the bar and waited on us was very pleasant and seemed to genuinely care that we were enjoying out visit. I really like places that are true to themselves and fit in well rather than catering to the pretentious hipster crowd. Definitely worth a return trip.

57.description: Love this place. It's the perfect little neighborhood spot. They have great casual food choices and a wonderful beer selection. My favorites food-wise include the massive onion rings, the juicy burgers and their fish and chips. The sloppy joe was quite delicious, too. The service is generally very friendly and down-to-earth. Their juke box is also a real treat with tons of great oldies jams to choose from. I highly recommend checking this place out.

20.description: Amazing pierogis and pretty delicious meat loaf. The waitress was very sweet. The ambience is a little dive bar-ish but cute. Will definitely go again!

36.description: I had been excited to visit Four Moon Tavern due to the excellent reviews, cool name, & legendary grilled cheese.I am NEVER going back.While the grilled cheese was fine, one bartender was so RUDE, I will never patronize this establishment again. Her condescension and attitude were appalling. There was no reason for her behavior and I can spend my money elsewhere.

14.description: Another great place in my neighborhood!The food is outstanding and surprising for a local pub. Different nightly specials. Always a good craft beer on special and a nice selection on booze. The staff is so freaking nice too! The crowd is neighborhood folks but not too Roscoe Village ish. It's a little more chill.I love the wooden decor. Makes me feel like I'm in the UP! This is now a weekly stop for us.  Well done! :)

1.description: Dull.Nothing "retro" about it. I knew Roscoe Village hasn't really ever had anything "retro" for awhile, apart from being an insulated blue-collar area stuck in 1967 until yuppies knocked down your grandpa's wooden two-flat 10 years ago. Don't come expecting vintage books, art, records, or other things that might earn the name "retro."The car show was somewhat good. As a classic car enthusiast myself, I enjoyed the paltry offering of cars that most of the strolling yuppies could care less about. Who needs a car when you can take an Uber to Mariano's 2 blocks away?Food choices were abysmal. What little that was offered were sausages and other fried garbage. We ate at the Banh Mi place instead. Overpriced cans of beer. And so, so many vendors, especially Red Baron Pizza and Cupcake wine with multiple large displays. Felt like more of a trade show than a local street festival. Doesn't matter. Every pocket neighborhood on the favored Northside of Chicago has to have its own street festival which are similar, if not the same (i.e Star Events).

9.description: Well, you know. This is managed by Star Events.  It has the same 4 cover bands they have for every fest.  Such a shame with such a great music scene in Chicago.  I mean, Really? Retro?  Really?  Along with the 80s cover bands come some terrible beer and food choices, at least.  That being said, it's not entirely horrific if you go in the afternoon, I guess? Not to argue with the other reviewers, but peeeyoooo.  I will definitely take a pass.

12.description: I attended this festival for the first time this year, having just returned to Chicago after a long stint in CA. Perhaps I'm just spoiled by all the other fests, but I didn't find this one to be all that appealing in terms of the music. For the most part, the musicianship was great, but it was what they played that I found really generic. Again, if you're with a bunch of people who like to dance, it could be okay. That wasn't the case for me, however.Anyone who really enjoys mostly cover music will probably do okay here. I've never seen so many people just sort of "standing" -- not moving at all, to what was essentially dance music. I love to dance, but no one I was with was interested and I wasn't gonna go out there and go "dancin' with myself." Not in broad daylight, anyway. The atmosphere is fun, but boy did they ever get a late start! I was there for the beginning and the crowd was so thin that Second City, who graciously had improv performers there, canceled their gig because there were basically no people at 12:30 . . . they were scheduled to go on at 12. I was really disappointed. But because I showed up and was enthusiastic, they guys took pity on me and gave me a drop in and house ensemble passes, which I fully intend to take advantage of. When I was living in the Gold Coast, I used to frequent the after-show improvs whenever I could.And now back to our program. There are tons of booths with stuff being sold, which is usually what goes on at any fest. I get that. But I'm one of those people who really enjoys original music by local bands. And the street food, which looked good, but I was uninspired and opted to have some beverages and leave after a few hours.I really wanted to love this fest, but alas, I can't say that I did. That would be a lie. And I do not lie in my reviews. I think this fest is also really great for kids -- there is a lot for them to do and it didn't seem as overcrowded as some of the other fests tend to get.I'm sure that I probably won't go at all next year, unless the people I go with like to dance!

21.description: Went here last night to see 16 candles play.  As usual, the band was great, however it was def. more packed than normal.  It was hard to just get beer and go to the port a potties.  So, I was limited to stand with the crowd and be hidden behind everyone (I'm 5 ft. tall).  Would go again to see bands, but don't expect it to be a leisurely day.

16.description: What's better than attending this fest on Roscoe, you say? Volunteering! See me at the beer stand. If you don't like the band in front of you then go to the next 3 others that are playing. Don't forget to say "hi"

17.description: Maybe it was the awesome Saturday night weather.  Maybe it was the group I was with.  Maybe it is the cute cute area of Roscoe Village.  I LOVE Retro on Roscoe. I love the area, I love the bands. I love the vendors, I love the people. I love the white wine sangria from Rebel/Waterhouse.  I was in full on "loving this mode"Too White Crew, Hairbangers.  Also I just found out that Mike and Joe is a great cover band.  Why no one told me this and it is almost the end of fest season, I will never know.  (Argh)  In any case, Retro on Roscoe is the bees knees. Go for the music, stay for the atmosphere. It looked like the vendors were local businesses so support your local businesses  as well!!

10.description: This is one of the fests that we keep visiting year after year.  Very laid back, well laid out, family friendly and great food and entertainment make this one of our favorite fests. There's something for everyone here.  A section for the little ones, complete with an artist creating balloon animals.  There's the different booths selling beaded jewelry, clothing, purses and my favorite this year--wooden retro-looking signs with cute slogans/sayings.  Got a cute sign saying "Go Jump in the Lake" for my cousin's lake house. I liked that they had white or red sangria for purchase in case you're not in the mood for beer.  Typical fest food--deep fried goodies, grilled meats, fruit slushies and what I really wanted to try this year--Cevapici! The music was good and kept everyone in a happy mood.  As others have said, lots of strollers so watch your feet!

5.description: Definitely one of the, if not the best festivals of the season. Terrific beer and food selection, along with some great music on 3 stages. Car show for the gearheads to boot!

11.description: This is a pretty cool festival.  It almost has a carnival atmosphere in this area.  Lots of games and other junk like that.  That will bring along kids with their parents (this is the Roscoe Village/North Center/Hamlin Park area afterall).There are no D-bags that you can find in Lincoln Park, there is no attitudes.  Just come and enjoy the good times.The only thing that weirded me out was the dude selling butterflies that he killed and mounted between glass.  Leia and I talked to him (cause that was weird to see at a fair), and he said that he and his wife own a butterfly farm in Peru.  Then he said its not really a farm, as he does not raise them nor have a mesh roof to keep them in there, more like a piece of land that butterfly's naturally go to.  So it turns out he kills them and mounts them.  The whole time I couldn't help to think that he uses his proceeds to purchase his yearly subscription to World of Warcraft.  I bet he's pawning newbs right now (did I say that correct?).My best tip on this place is go to Lush wine and spirits to buy your beers to walk around and drink.  You can get a good good beer for $5 instead of crappy bud.Plus who doesn't love Hair Bangers Ball, 16 Candles, Mike and Joe, and Too White Crew?

22.description: No popped collars!  Yey!!!!  There were, however, some sweater dresses (really?) and a bit of teased 80s hair.There was an abundance of beer / beverage tents and food choices.  Since I had the foresight to bring my own sangria (!) I did not need to purchase any....  As far as bathrooms go, we hopped out of the festival and into Mulligans, bought a shot, used the bathroom, and were on our merry way.  (Mulligans, by the way, has expanded and it's looking pretty nice!)The festival crowd, for the most part, was a vast improvement over Lincoln Park's people.  Too White Crew was the first band we saw; they were good, but not necessarily one I'd plan my festival around.  Sixteen Candles didn't disappoint.If I weren't going to Lollapalooza today, I'd be back for day 2 on Retro on Roscoe!

0.description: One of my favorite festivals. Probably helps that it's just down the street from my house but also because the music is my kind of songs. Yeah, it's a kid heavy neighborhood so be prepared for the stroller brigade but it's not too bad.Met the Yelp rep here. He told me about the monocle feature that Yelp now has. Had no idea! Very cool!

20.description: Retro on Roscoe was a pleasant way to spend a Saturday afternoon with the girls. We enjoyed reasonably-priced sangria (one glass was enough for me) before meandering through the fest.While there were several "duplicate" stands selling similar items (faux designer sunglasses, for example), there were more unique handmade jewelry stands than I've seen at some of the other neighbourhood fests. We also found some pretty reversible dress/skirts, which the vendor patiently showed us how to tie in a number of different ways.Vegans can gobble down the seitan tacos available from Big Bite Catering; the same stand also had veggie burgers. They were quite generous with the seitan. They did not, however, offer extras such as tomatoes, only baby lettuce.The bands on multiple stages played songs I remember my older sister listening to 15 years ago, such as the Gin Blossoms. There is a whole end of the fest just for the kiddies: mini-mini-golf, inflatable bouncy things, facepainting, etc. It's a fairly family-friendly event.I wasn't a fan of the portable ATMs in the fest. It decided to randomly quit while processing the transaction, leaving me without my cash and wondering if it will be deducted from my account anyway.I think the street lends itself to being a good fest location. There are several vintage shops, cute boutiques and small restaurants all along the perimeter in case you need to step inside for a moment.

19.description: No popped collars!  Yey!!!!  There were, however, some sweater dresses (really?) and a bit of teased 80s hair.There was an abundance of beer / beverage tents and food choices.  Since I had the foresight to bring my own sangria (!) I did not need to purchase any....  As far as bathrooms go, we hopped out of the festival and into Mulligans, bought a shot, used the bathroom, and were on our merry way.  (Mulligans, by the way, has expanded and it's looking pretty nice!)The festival crowd, for the most part, was a vast improvement over Lincoln Park's people.  Too White Crew was the first band we saw; they were good, but not necessarily one I'd plan my festival around.  Sixteen Candles didn't disappoint.If I weren't going to Lollapalooza today, I'd be back for day 2 on Retro on Roscoe!

2.description: How could I not love the perennial summer fest that is literally two blocks down from my house?  It hasn't really changed since the first time we attended 1 month after moving into Roscoe Village in 2012.  The money goes to our local schools and neighborhood projects...hopefully that includes the roads and fixing the drainage on certain corners that flood after a major rainfall like at Roscoe & Wolcott and Roscoe & Seeley...I digress.Always enjoy Hairbangers Ball - they put on a great set and show with their outfits and coordinating big hair wigs, although one of the guitarists rocks naturally long curls.  This year we also checked out Too White Crew, which was also entertaining.  Not only did they do "Rumpshaker" and the staple "Ice Ice Baby", but also some Nelly songs and my personal college throwback "Back That Thang Up".  The girls were better than the guys ("Waterfalls", "Creep", "Shoop", etc).  Sixteen Candles plays the usual crowd singalong pleasers.  There are a variety of food stations - I tried the Fat Shallot food truck (as featured on the Food Network) and their Grilled Cheese, which was good except for the spinach they snuck into the sandwhich.  Their truffle fries were okay.  The sangria stations have really good red and white sangria - not diluted, flavorful, and full of fruit chunks.It is a family friendly fest so watch the strollers, kids, dogs, and people reliving their 70-80s youth.  Beats the crowds at the other fests.  You may get hit by the occasional air guitar or white person jumping to Van Halen's "Jump" or gaggle of white women dancing and singing "Scrubs".  We are in Roscoe Village after all.

18.description: Found this festival to be one of the most boring one ever. It's a yuppie family feast. Everything was sooo overpriced too.

13.description: Same crappy 80's cover bands that play EVERY lame street festival these days...That play the SAME SONGS !!Same crowd of "I'm too old to be single" drunks that migrated to The Village from Schaumburg.Chicken on a stick, wee hoo...actually pretty good really.Can't wait to here The Outfield every hour and a half.Way to go Chicago !Time to fire someone.

4.description: Too White Crew, Hairbanger's Ball, 90's cover bands, hot moms, cool sangria, good friends, good times. Retro on Roscoe 2012 was kind of a repeat of 2010, when I last attended, and I've had a blast both years. Nothing really makes Retro stand apart from any of the other Chicago Fests, but it just seems like a relaxed Fest where people come out to have a great time. Slight knock for not having a better beer selection, but you could head to LUSH wine and spirits and come back w/some Daisy Cutter tall boys, if so inclined. And many of the bars on Roscoe rock it 'til the wee hours, afterward.

6.description: You can't go wrong with 16 Candles....Came here on Saturday night to meet up with a few different groups of friends.  Had a great time.  The crowd at this street fest was a little tamer and more family friendly than other street fests, which was kind of nice.  I don't spend much time in Roscoe Village, but all the cute shops and restaurants make me want to go back.  I wish I had gone to the street fest earlier to enjoy it more.

15.description: I came into this festival with such high hopes only to have it end with crushing disappointment, emotions reminding me of when I learned a donor had been found for my kidney transplant, only to discover that donor was Amy Winehouse.  With 5 blocks of overpriced food, worthless trinkets, and gimmick games, I haven't seen this much wasted real estate since Kevin Federlein built a home recording studio.  I even heard one Native American mutter, "You guys stole our land for this??"   The food features $7 sausage sandwiches and $9 hamburgers.  Yes, nine dollars.  Or as confused German festival-goers said, "Dollars?  Nein!"  For $5, I played one of the carnival games in which I was handed 3 darts and asked to pop balloons.  Although I popped all the balloons, none qualified me to win a big prize, but the girl at the booth gave me a smiley-face key ring.  I felt touched (not so much in an emotional way, but more of a Jerry Sandusky way).  So be warned if you play any of the games.  A dyslexic has a better chance of winning Wheel of Fortune.  The lone bright spot of the evening was a shaggy street magician who put his colleague into a box before sticking a bunch of knives into it.  Then the kids (and interested adults) were invited to go and peer into the box to see the colleague twist his body in such a way that he avoided all the knives.  Yes, clearly these guys were going places, provided those places weren't the barber, the dentist, or the high school equivalency testing center.  And as usual with these festivals, they ask for an entry fee ($10 was what I heard), but remember, like stopping at red lights or foreplay, it is purely optional. The headliner musical act on Sunday night was called Wedding Band.  If this is any indication of the music that takes place at real weddings, it explains the high rate of divorce in America.  The off-key screeching would have annoyed deaf people.  Indeed, the last person to do this much damage to the human ear was Vincent Van Gogh.  Not that I have a problem with cover bands, mind you.  If you can entertain and make a good living off someone else's work, go for it (which reminds me, I need to send Mark Zuckerburg a birthday card and then go read some Shakespeare).  It was more the song selection -- Chumba Wumba and Fountains of Wayne?  I was looking forward to getting Alzheimer's so I could forget about them.  Good thing we left before they moved on to Hanson and the Spice Girls.

7.description: Horrible cover bands. Bad food. Crappy art. If you live in the neighborhood, within a block of the stretch of street this festival takes place on, Retro on Roscoe is the worst thing to happen all year. Two full days and nights of trying to merely exist in your home without wanting to rip your hair out for the terrible music. Retro on Roscoe, you couldn't end soon enough. No increase in volume on my television could possibly drown out the horror of bad cover bands playing country versions of Lady Gaga songs.

8.description: If you're not a fan of small children or the stroller set don't come here while the sun's still out.You can thank me later.

3.description: Food vendors were good but the website made it seem as if there would be antique vendors or at least more shopping to be had than the few subpar tents available. Was not worth the $10 "suggested" donation.

14.description: Retro on Roscoe is one of the bigger and better fests held during the summer.  It's not as big as Taste of Lincoln Avenue, but I think it's better.  You know once Retro is over that the best of the fest season is also over with it and that it's time to start looking forward to smaller fests and cooler temps.  Retro is shockingly a fest just like all the other fests.  It's people standing in the street drinking beer, eating and listening to music.  But it is one of the better fests for some reason.  I think it's because I've always met friendly people there and run into people I know.  It's certainly not the hot mess that is Taste of Lincoln Avenue.  This year, Retro did the beer situation up right.  They set up a beer truck with taps on both sides and surrounded it with high top rectangular tables, which acted as a impromptu bar.  Great call.  Getting beer at this fest was a snap.  Other fests should take heed of this small, but important, detail.  Another important detail Retro got right this year, after several years of failing, was the portable outhouses.  They had plenty of them this year, and they were clean.  You can't underestimate how important the outhouse situation is at a fest.  In years past, Retro's outhouse situation was a long line of 50 people.  That's not quick enough for several beers on a somewhat empty stomach.  Good job, Retro, for rectifying that situation this year.As for the bands, it was the usual stuff you see every weekend at fests - Hairbanger's Ball and Sixteen Candles for the 149th time.  We opted to remain on the Hairbanger's side right by the beer the entire night.  They are actually incorporating "Bad Romance" into their set list these days right next to Metallica.  Uh, okay.  The volunteers at Retro get cool t-shirts to wear for the fest.  They have an "O" on the front with a "retr" encased within the "O."  This year's t-shirt was white with red trim.  I always thought the design of these was pretty sharp.  The ex had a blue one and a brown one from her days of volunteering at Retro.  Loved the blue one.  Hated the brown one.  Miraculously, I did not cross paths with her at this fest for the first time in five years.  Whoa-oh-oh-oh-ooooh-oh-oh-oh-ooh, whoa-oh-oh.  Just kidding.  How's yer ma?Five stars for Retro.  I'll be back to Roscoe for the Guinness Oyster Fest next month.

58.description: The food is good.  The service is okay.  I really like sitting on the sidewalk in Roscoe Village though.  And I like wine.  And it's open when Frasca isn't, which is probably where I would choose if I wanted something Italian-y in Roscoe Village.

56.description: Love love this place!Lupe makes you feel welcomed and comfortable as soon as you step though there doors. The food is delicious and reasonably priced. The atmosphere is welcoming and cozy. The service is even better. I've gone to this place a good number of times and will most definitely continue to go back! My number one recommendation is the bruschetta, best in town.

29.description: My favorite spot for Italian in Chicago hands down. I saw a couple negative reviews lately so I wanted to put in my say. The sauce there is always made just right. It is really hard to find a place that can actually use the right consistency in their Italian sauces. Portions are huge and we always end up taking food home.Service is great. They can be kind of corny at times but it adds a nice level of humor and personality to the place. I'm always excited to go back. I'm used to the tacky "Italian" restaurants downtown with all the glitz of high prices and basic dishes. This is a huge step up from anything you would find downtown or at a chain dining establishment.

42.description: Where do I begin? Why isn't there a "no" star rating?I have been patronizing this eatery since it opened years ago.  That was a more pleasant time with superb food, warm and welcoming staff and a place where the owners remembered your name. But then new management took over. Since that time, their overly expensive and very forgettable menu, lost me as a customer.I used to eat there once a week and then get delivery about the same. It was SO worth it! Fresh food, perfectly seasoned, great service and very knowledgeable staff. The new owners had big shoes to fill and they failed and failed some more.A week ago, I ordered food for delivery and two hours later was still waiting. I spoke to Lupe and he was apologetic and said he would return the cost of the meal, which he did. He also said that he would comp my next order. Great! So I ordered delivery last night. Carpaccio, eggplant/potato appetizers, fusili, thin crust Margherita Pizza and a cannoli. It arrived in the time promised but as soon as I opened the bag I knew this was going to be a disaster. Wrong pizza, which was a soggy salty mess laden with ingredients that had nothing to do with my order. The eggplant appetizer was totally wrong, Caprese salad was substituted for carpaccio (there was none to be had in the house), the fusili was an over cooked salty, mushy mess. In short, the entire meal was inedible. The cannoli was a cloyingly pasty puddle of goo that was obviously not fresh.When I initially called to speak with Lupe to make sure that he remembered his promise to comp my meal I was told by the phone person that he had gone home for the night, so she took the order (she was also the same employee who took my botched order several days before). When I called back to let her know about the latest order being a nightmare, I asked for Lupe and she said he was busy. What?In short, a disorganized, unknowledgeable staff, overcooked and over salted food and an eatery that thought that  it could ride the coat tails of the original owners and the stellar reputation they established. What a shame. It will be interesting to see how long this joint stays open. Never again.

23.description: I am such a fan of Piazza Bella.  My fiancee and I have been here probably 10 times.  It took a couple times for me to find the right dish for me.  Their wine selections is really good.  They have Nobilo SB which is one of my all-time favorite wines.  I really like the gnocchi they serve there.  Seriously, the gnocchi is so tender and it literally melts in your mouth.  I asked the server about it one time and I guess they cook it in a special way that makes it especially tender.  Their vegetarian pizzas are also very good.  However, it's their desserts that really rock my socks.  The cannoli and the creme brule are amazing.  Everyone I have gone with also rave about the tiramisu, but I'm not a tiramisu person.  The decor is cute and the staff is friendly.  I take most of my visitors to the Roscoe Village neighborhood here.  Definitely would recommend!

47.description: I've gone to Piazza Bella twice, and both times were great. The staff is friendly and knowledgeable, and they don't rush you through your meal. The food's a bit pricey, but good. I HIGHLY recommend the tortellini w peas and prosciutto!

8.description: Piazza Bella has awesome Italian food in Roscoe Village... the waiter (Jeff) was awesome and super chatty! We even had a shot of limoncello as our dessert with him!Food was good and they are very accommodating whether you want to change something on the entrée. Overall it was a great experience and when I am in the area I will stop by again for more goodness!

31.description: Won't be back.Used to be a decent, go-to Italian joint in the neighborhood.  But like many other yelpers, we were shocked by the new menu. This was not just a menu update.  It's like they asked around to find out what the most popular dishes were - and then DELETED ALL OF THEM!  So weird.  They had several great chicken dishes that are all gone, the ONLY chicken option left is a $25 half-chicken!  Many of the best pasta dishes were removed as well.  I used to have a tough time deciding between my many favorites; this time I couldn't find a thing to order.  I ended up with a plain bowl of pasta with diced tomatoes.  I can make it better, and a lot cheaper, at home.Menu is smaller, servings are smaller, and prices are bigger.  Very unfortunate that a local restaurant is now off the list.  Used to be a favorite, but we will not be back.

34.description: Went there last night....first time in a while. It's one of our go-to restaurants when we want some good Italian. First, noticed the new menu which has squid ink linguini so I was a happy man. I understand when you have a new menu for the first time in 10 years it will rub some people the wrong way, but this was a complete overhaul. No more risotti, and some of our favorite dishes are gone. The food was delicious but the size portions are not the same (but the prices are). Felt like they did a Restaurant Impossible episode here and they are more focused on the $$. The west side of the restaurant looked completely closed. Hope they make it but not a fan of the changes other than the Squid Ink Linguini.....probably wont be back. Also heard a few other table lementing the changes (no gelato for example). Service is great.

16.description: I feel my three star review is actually quite generous given how hit or miss Piazza Bella can be. I was excited that there was a neighborhood Italian place since I moved away from my beloved Caro Mio, but Piazza Bella does not even compare. I've dined at Piazza Bella for brunch and dinner. Their brunch service is decent, it is a buffet. No major issues with the food or service, and the price is pretty good. Also, you usually don't have to wait to have brunch unlike the other popular brunch establishments in the neighborhood. Dinner however, is a completely different story. The dishes range from "not bad" to "wtf is this?". On my most recent visit, a pasta dish was ordered that you could add shrimp to for an additional $6. We waited almost 45 minutes for the food to arrive, and when it did the pasta dish had three shrimp on it. That's $2 dollars a shrimp folks! Insane. The pizza I had was fine...this time. A later visit I was given pizza with dough that was not completely cooked. Some dinner pluses include the lasagna. My mom ordered it when visiting me and she loved it. I tried it and it was pretty good. So you see, by eating at Piazza Bella, you take a risk. A risk of having to wait ages for food, being disappointed in the food, and paying too much for the food.
