I've been there with just adults and with kids in the evening and they suit the atmosphere to the time of day. Kids are good until 7pm I would guess. In the summer it's nice with the patio doors open and in the winter it feels so authentic and cozy inside. The staff are great esp the owner.

50.description: Que rico has a lot going for them.  To start off positive, the restaurant itself is very cute and they have a nice outdoor area in the summer.  Its right by our place in roscoe village so i was very excited to have a go to mexican place in our 'hood.  What Que rico does not have going for them is the food. In fact the food is horrible.   I'll agree the margs are strong..but not good.. so i'm not sure that a plus.   The burrito was completely tasteless.  I would consider going back if the food was just OK...but its not.  Its too bad because the place has so much potential--it just goes not deliver.

4.description: I have been going to Que Rico for years and always have a great experience.  The meat and veggies in the fajitas are not dry (a refreshing change from many other restaurants), and the margaritas are excellent.  It is a family-owned restaurant that takes a real interest in its customers.  The patio cannot be beat when the weather warms.

6.description: I don't know what everyone's talking about... this place is solid!Great warm non-greasy chips and a tasty/spicy salsa!Delicious fajitas, margaritas!My husband enjoyed the Monterrey chicken. The one point down is that the guac could have been a bit more flavorful, but mixed with the salsa it was great!

22.description: My boyfriend and I came here on a Friday night in May. We wanted some place where we could sit outside and unwind after a long work week and Que Rico was close by. Luckily for a Friday, we were seated outside upon arrival. We ordered a pitcher of margaritas and they brought us chips and salsa. The margarita was extremely strong and it seemed to be basically just tequila, ice, and lemon. The chips were unsalted/pretty hard and didn't seem fresh. We ordered our entrees and some queso fundido for an appetizer. The fundido was good, but our meals were not memorable. Overall I give Que Rico 3 stars - the patio was nice, the food was OK, the drinks were strong. We will probably go back due to proximity.

15.description: Que Rico = Que No NoVery cute restaurant - warm orange walls, nice lighting, outdoor patio area - the atmosphere was better than the food.  Came here for a Friday night dinner date after passing by the place many times and wanting to try it.  We sat outside in the enclosed patio area, which was nice, and started with a pitcher of margaritas - a little too sweet, with a lot too much ice in the pitcher.  Food: I ordered the chx chimichanga, the man ordered some kind of exotic sounding spiced chicken / rice dish.  My plate had three small changas with tiny dollops of guac + sour cream, served with mini portions of bland beans, rice, and shredded lettuce.  This was priced and listed as an entree, but really should be considered an appetizer, because that was its equivalent. The man's exotic sounding chx dish turned out to be something on par with what we could easily make at home: cook some rice, add a can of tomatoes + chx.  Voila. With some TLC [ a menu overhaul complete with spices / flavor, fixing of the deteriorating outdoor signs, more on-spot service ] this place could be really nice. Until then, adiós Rico...

57.description: M to-the A to-the G.A.R to-the I.T.A  What's that spell?!  MARGARITA baby and let's make that strong!  I decided to order a half pitcher of the plain old margarita and... I was ready to dance on the table by only the second glass.  I'll definitely be back for those babies who guide me through fun times.  However, the food is plain and bland, terribly overpriced, and not worth it.  We weren't able to sit outside because it was too cold, but it looks like a great place to bring friends and drink (plus, if the rooftop we saw from the car is true, what a place to be in the summer!!)

20.description: This place needs to step up the food.  Every two years I try this place again as the memory of the last mediocre dinner fades.  At least they are consistent. ....

36.description: I went here for dinner with a friend this summer, so we sat outside. We ordered maragaritas and dinner. The drinks were not good and over-priced. The food was expensive and the plate sizes were small. Service was slow and not attentive, perhaps due to the warm weather, but regardless, I'm paying a decent amount of money and am being really nice, so I expect pretty good service. I didn't enjoy the experience at all, so I would not recommend coming here at all.

14.description: Como se dice en Espanol "mediocre?"That's all this place is. The food can be beaten almost anywhere else. Service is not exceptional. Even the atmosphere is a little blah; it's usually empty! If your heart is set on Mexican and you're in the area, I'd send you over to Tony's.

3.description: Finally! A Dunkin Donuts that foes the coffee perfectly, warms up the bagel exactly to the point where the smoked salmon doesn't just sit there but melt perfectly right! Seriously I am a DD freak and I say it as I see it and I rarely give 5 stars to any place (see my reviews). I am just chessin with a smile because I always dread going to DD's I don't frequent. But this one hit it on the head! It's right across the street from Lane Tech and it is 8 PM and I am just grateful they did it right because today has been the day of HELL! Great job!I would definitely go there over and over, but its so far from me! And just for your info, Coffee after 1 pm is $1!

1.description: I am not sure I can tell the difference between one dunkin donuts to another but I guess if I went more often I would know the difference. This location is very clean, the staff is friendly and usually everything you order comes quickly. I usually don't ever get the same thing twice but I do love a good donut every once in awhile and dunkin usually hits the spot.

2.description: I love my neighborhood Dunkin Donuts.  I live right around the corner and just love that I have gone here enough now that the women know me and have my coffee ready how I like it.  They tolerate my three kids changing their minds 10 times about which donut they actually want and will sometimes sneek in a free munchkin for them to try.I have always had great service here and have been very pleased with my visits which are at least 2-3 times a week for coffee.  Thanks!

5.description: Basically, this is your typical Dunkin' Donuts.  However, the service is what matters to me.  During the school year, this Dunkin is packed with students every morning and yet the employees keep the line moving.  They remember regulars and greet you courteously every time.  They even remember my order!  Pretty impressive!

6.description: This is one of the worst DD I have ever gone to. This is what happened. I went to get an iced caramel coffee- cream no sugar. Simple right? I get interviewed for what kind of syrup, how much sugar (i said no sugar), do I want sauce of flavoring, or syrup. I have never been asked so many questions. And than the coffee...well it was iced milk with a touch of coffee. I asked for more coffee less cream....i got it..not without a dirty look. Ended up with ok coffee, and one ice cube..didnt even bother asking for more ice for the fear for my life.

7.description: This is a great place for fast service.  They remember the way I want my coffee everytime I come in.  Very friendly fast efficient service.

8.description: I'm generally a big fan of Dunkin Donuts, especially the chocolate glazed muchkins...but this location is not exactly my favorite. Last few times I went here, they charged me for cream and sugar for my coffee....Isn't that supposed to be included?!!?

9.description: dunky's is tops in my book.  its bascially cream and sugar with a splash of coffee--they really know how to make deeelicious coffee.  mmmm...such a yummy treat.i'm also eternally in love with "the breakfast sandwich".  don't let the name fool you, these puppies are available any time, day or nite.  in fact, i think the breakfast sandwich is most appreciated during a late-nite drunkin donuts visit.also, i totes appreciate that when i ask for a munchkin or two, they usually just give it to me.

0.description: I live right around the corner from this place, and get the exact same flavored iced coffee at every location I go to. This is the only location that gets what I order every day, perfect. I tell every DD employee the same order, but the drink doesn't always turn out the same. I wonder why.The employees at this location are so friendly. I've lost my debit/visa, because of forgetting it at this DD location. Instead of trying to use it as a credit card and steal money off of it, it was returned to me.I locked myself out of my apartment once (while taking the garbage out), had nothing but my shoes and coat... walked over to this DD off of addison and western and one of the women working let me use her cell phone. I've had good experiences with every single employee at this location. The women during the day, the guy that spends evenings there, and other males working a number of different shifts. They remember my drink order by heart, and though there are a ridiculous amount of Dunkin' locations, this one has always been my preference.The ONLY thing that I could do without is Lane Tech being across the street. Too many teenagers.

4.description: Cheerful staff, especially in the morning where the lady at the counter knows my order by heart even when I haven't been there in a while. Food is good, just a tad overcooked on toasted items but it is still tasty nonetheless. Bagels with cream cheese - excellent.Overnight guy is friendly but likes to hide in the back which is slightly annoying when um you need that coffee fix.Oh they sometimes give me hazelnut iced coffee when I want coconut so I solved that problem by ordering mocha almond from now on.

58.description: This has become my go to thin crust pizza. For the last several years, I've been looking for a favorite for thin crust, and I've tried everything. I was starting to think that Rosati's was my favorite, until I found Bartoli's. Bartoli's thin crust pizza is some of the best that I've ever had. The pizza always comes fresh, hot, and SQUARE CUT! Nothing drives me crazier in the pizza game more than a pizza that's not square cut! Besides the thin crust pizza, I haven't tried the other menu items. Just judging from the pizza, I'd be willing to bet that their other items are just as good. If you're looking for good thin crust pizza, look no further.

56.description: My husband and I consider ourselves experts when it comes to Chicago style pizza. We both agree, hands down, Bartoli's is the best deep dish in the city. We even dare to say it is better than Lou Malnati's and Giordanos! Everything about it is perfect from the sauce to the crispness of the crust. We love this spot and have recommended it to many who have loved it, too. Whether you eat in or have it at home, you won't be disappointed. Highly recommend the spinach and mushroom!

29.description: I got "Bartoli's Chicago Classic" which has Italian sausage, mushroom, onions and green peppers. Deep dish is a must if you're in Chicago and this place is definitely one of the top deep dishes I've ever had. Service and environment was great and friendly. I would recommend this place, you won't be disappointed!!

42.description: Great pizza joint. Both the thin crust and deep dish are outstanding. We have also had the meatball sandwich---hearty and a good deal. Staff are very nice. They usually have sports playing inside on a large tv and outdoor seating during the summer. We live a block away so this is our go to pizza place.

23.description: There is a few times in my life where the pizza place does me justice in this city. Needless to say...BARTOLLIS HAS DELIVERED. This girl Nora I believe her name was has changed the game giving me suggestions. I came in uncertain and I came out eating pizza I didn't think left the dream realm! 10/10 Nora is amazing

47.description: If you want the best pizza in Chicago this is the place.  I first tried Bartoli's in February or early March of 2014 when a friend ordered delivery for a birthday party.  So yummy!  Since then I have been back a few times to dine in their BYOB tiny dining room.  You order and pay at the counter and then find a seat and they bring you your food when it is ready.  Brian the owner, his Mom who works there too, and the entire staff are very kind and work super hard to make sure that the customer experience and quality of food is top caliber.  I recommend that people drive, take the CTA, hire a cab, walk, bike, etc to come here if someone wants delicious pizza.  It's also a great place for a small gathering as they let you bring in BYOB as well as a birthday cake yet you probably need a reservation for a larger group.  They also have pizza by the slice that is ready to go.The only recommendation is to offer more selections of sodas in cans at a lower price.  Many people don't want the larger portion or price in the plastic bottles that are sold and on the menu it lists a can of soda for 95 cents yet the only option is root beer in a can.  Truly...the best in Chicago! Bravo!  I thank my friend Mike for introducing me to Bartoli's.

8.description: Great thin crust and deep dish- something for everyone. The menu is pretty extensive with apps and sandwiches as well. Although the restaurant is small; it is cute for dining in. Plus there is a mart across the street to take care of the BYOB.

31.description: Pretty good pizza, decent beef. The owner seemed like a good dude; we chit chatted a bit while i dined in during my lunch break. The staff were all really friendly,  and very competent.  Overall a pretty well run, solid pizzeria.

34.description: Couldn't ask for a better neighborhood pizza joint! I like the deep dish spinach and sausage. The thin crust stockyard (pie cut) is my other go to, but it's definitely on the saltier side. My order is not complete unless I've got a 1/2 lb of cheese curds. I normally feel like crap after eating all that, but its sooo damn good! Pretty sad I'm moving out of the Village and will have to find a new go-to pizza spot.

16.description: This has become my go to thin crust pizza. For the last several years, I've been looking for a favorite for thin crust, and I've tried everything. I was starting to think that Rosati's was my favorite, until I found Bartoli's. Bartoli's thin crust pizza is some of the best that I've ever had. The pizza always comes fresh, hot, and SQUARE CUT! Nothing drives me crazier in the pizza game more than a pizza that's not square cut! Besides the thin crust pizza, I haven't tried the other menu items. Just judging from the pizza, I'd be willing to bet that their other items are just as good. If you're looking for good thin crust pizza, look no further.

13.description: Yum .Really delicious pizza. Moving out of the neighborhood and was just discussing how I'd come back here and eat. Ordered a medium deep dish and large thin for four of us and it went quickly. Really flavorful and cooked perfectly. Driver was also here faster than we were quoted. Will definitely eat here again!

11.description: Bartoli's is a quick medium sized pizza place a couple miles west of Wrigley Field off of Addison. It is within walking distance from the Brown line. (This is where I was coming from and stopped by here) There is also a westbound Addison bus stop just across the street. Service here was friendly and prompt. I simply got a slice of pizza in an individual to go box and I was waiting for the bus a minute later. The pizza was good and again quick and convenient. It was not that busy but it was clean and seemed orderly. They have a television and seating for those who would like to eat their slice there.

39.description: Just ordered bartollis for the first time....must say it's absolutely delicious. I ordered half pineapple and half sausage thin crust. The sauce is amazing the crust is great. My only regret is that I ordered a large instead of an extra large because it was all devoured in less then ten minutes. I just found my new favorite pizza spot in the neighborhood...

37.description: No frills, just awesome Chicago style pizza!Drove 2 hrs. to eat here...totally worth it.Located in nice area with plenty of free parking available on the street. Bring your "Big Boy" appetite if you order the "Chicago Stock Yard".

0.description: Seriously underrated stuffed pizza!! When it comes to Chicago style pizza be it stuffed or deep dish, I would have to say:1. Pequods2. Bartoli's3. Lou Malnati'sYes. I would say it ranks #2 in my top 3. If you haven't tried it yet, don't wait!

38.description: My go to! I love this place. I have only ever done delivery but they are always super fast.

51.description: First, the pizza is OK, but it is not exceptional. We had it delivered and it arrived crispy. I am not from Chicago, so I don't get the square cut. I have a problem reviewing pizza since a lot of pizzas are really similar. I had the thin pizza, which I guess is not a Chicago thing. Perhaps their deep dish is the really special deal. I don't think most people would be disappointed by the thin crust and if I were in the area again I would probably order it.

27.description: My brothers and I were visiting from Arizona.  We are originally from Chicago. I was searching for a good Chicago Style Deep Dish Pizza.  I was not disappointed. This pizza was unbelievably delicious.  We got the Chicago Stockyard. OMG, it was full of meat and ingredients. I could not make it through my second piece it was so filling.  Good pizza and the Bears playing on the big screen TV. It doesn't get any better than that. Back in Phoenix and I am wishing there was one here.

32.description: I ordered from Bartoli's twice. After the first experience, I was excited. When I've ordered deep dish previously in Chicago, I tend to get soggy crusts with a lot of excess moisture on the top. My first pizza from Bartoli's couldn't have been more different. There wasn't any excess water/etc to be seen, and the crust was delicious and crispy.When I had family in town a couple weeks later, I wanted to treat them to some great deep dish, so I immediately opted for Bartoli's. Unfortunately, as soon as it arrived, I could tell this was a different experience. The delivery driver wasn't very careful with the pizza and all of the toppings had shifted to one half. There were pools of liquid all over the top of the pizza, and the box was just as soggy as the crust. I called to complain, but received nothing more than a weak I'm sorry. To their credit, they did offer to make a new one, but as I had hungry guests, waiting more than an hour for another pizza isn't quite appealing.I had thought I'd found my new go-to pizza place, but it appears I'll need to keep looking.

54.description: I need to be clear that I've only ever had their deep dish.  I've ordered it a few times and every time I'm more than satisfied.  The thing that is great is that the pizza freezes and reheats really well.  Last time I ordered, the delivery man was super friendly and said "you ordered the best pizza here!" as he walked up.  I like when delivery people are happy and don't act as though it's a chore.  And he was right - it's one of the best pizzas I've had in a long time.If I can't get Pequod's delivered, this is a close second.

48.description: Moving a few blocks away from here has not been a good thing for my waistline. Hands down, Bartoli's has one of the best thin crust pizzas I've been able to find in Chicago. The deep dish is also pretty good, and they always have slices if you're not feeling up to buying a whole pizza. The waffle fries are also greasy, amazing goodness. Definitely a great neighborhood spot!

44.description: Love their thin crust, love their cheese curds and love their deep dish spinach. Great service and good at estimating time it is done.  We drive and pick up - there is a flasher parking spot right in front that makes it easy to do with only one person.

24.description: Mama Mia, the meatball sandwich here was awesome. Their pizza isn't bad , but we tried their sandwiches for a change, and he italian beef  and meatball sandwiches were mucho Bella.

7.description: I didn't order a pizza but last night it was a very fast delivery! If it was supposed to be 30-45 mins, I got it no more than 15 minutes later. I ordered: buffalo wings, a salad and an Italian beef. Overall, the sandwich was great I also got waffle fries which were awesome. Haven't eaten the salad yet but it looks good, fancy cheese, good size croutons for a large portion.I guess I should have tipped more on my card knowing it would be so fast. The delivery guy seemed like he worked hard, so fear not Bartoli's, I'll hook you guys up in the future. Keep up the good work!

49.description: I ordered here last night thin medium pizza and hot wings. I live right by giordanos and chicagos pizza but i wanted to try a diff spot.My food came before the expected  delivery time yet wings were cold and pizza was warm and a bit underdone. I popped it back in the oven. Overall it was bland especially the hot wings no flavor also breaded and im not a fan of that style. Pizza had nice crust but sauce lacked flavor. I live by way to many great pizza places to ever order here again.

40.description: We love Bartolis! It's very close to where we live and so quick, easy and always friendly. The owners are almost always in the shop and ready to chat and talk with the customers. Some of the other workers are sometimes less than excited to be there... but they are young and I can totally relate to being that age. They've got "bigger and better" things to do, ha! Plus the kindness of the owners dismisses their (few) lack luster workers. The pizza is delicious! They offer deep dish and thin crust options. Along with a full menu of other items, but we always go in for the pizza. They have pizza by the slice! Which is so handy for a quick meal.The ambiance is great, love how welcoming and home-y the dinning room is. They almost always have "the game" (whatever game that might be) on, or just ask and they gladly will turn it on. The outdoor seating is great, and ample. Bonus? It's BYOB! And Sarah Mart is right across the street, if you need to grab a drink or two.Highly recommend this pizza shop!

53.description: My wife usually makes me get vegetarian pizzas, but I was blown away by the margherita pizza.  We've started getting it for our lazy dinner every Sunday.

30.description: Tonight was my second time ordering from Bartoli's. Sadly, they got my order wrong. However, when I called they were more then understanding and willing to give me a refund or make me a new pizza. I opted for a new pizza which they delivered as quickly as possible (within 30 mins). The new, correct pizza came hot, fresh and exactly what I ordered. Within 5 minutes of receiving my new pizza the owner himself called me to apologize for the mix up and the long wait time and even offered to make it up to me next time. What started off as a bad experience ended up wonderfully. They have excellent customer service. The pizza is also delicious. Last time I ordered the deep dish which was fantastic, this time I ordered thin crust, equally delicious.

46.description: The owner is a good guy, from the neighborhood, genuinely cares about his customers. He often reaches out for feedback and adjust his operations accordinglyThank you Brian

1.description: Okay, I'm trying really hard to like this place, as I did go against my better judgement to try it yet again.  Unfortunately, still don't think I will be back.  The guy at the counter when I walked in was nice, the reason two stars.  Otherwise, based on the food, one star.  I only stopped to grab a couple slices of pizza, again, just to give it another chance...I waited about five or ten minutes for them to rewarm a couple slices of deep dish sausage, which was still cold when we ate it.  As for the flavor, it was bland and totally lacking in any kind of signature flavor.  They guy made it very clear this is one they are know for; really?  Good luck, I just don't think they will survive long term in Chicago, too many better places.Sorry guys, I really did try again.  I can't understand the positive reviews on the pizza?  I can only think they have a lot of friends writing them, as they seem like nice people, more than restauranteurs.

55.description: Great Chicago style and a nice family atmosphere!

9.description: How am I so lucky that this place is top 10 on the Chicago Mag list, and steps from my house?Thin crust sausage (square pieces) even impresses my Chicago native mom's love for "cracker thin crust."  Deep dish has just the right cheese/sauce balance and a lightly butter crust.

26.description: I called in an order from here, and my husband signed for it when it was delivered. The driver had him sign the customer copy and didn't give us a copy of the receipt. When I checked our credit card statement, it showed a higher amount than my husband signed for. I called to complain, and they sent me a copy of the forged receipt they had on file -- the driver had written in his own (higher) tip on the merchant copy and forged *my* signature (my name was on the order, even though I didn't actually sign for it).After some back-and-forth with the dubious owner, he agreed to refund only the tip amount, despite the fact that what his driver did is actually a felony. Very bad business, will not be returning.

25.description: I am a Chicago guy -- and I love Lou Malnati's -- but I have to say Bartoli's flavor and pizza is just as good, if not better! When I asked about why it's so good, they told me the owner spent years perfecting his recipe prior to even opening Bartoli's Pizzeria. I also love taking my family here because it's a fun, family friendly atmosphere. The ownership is usually there, so I also feel like the service is at a higher level than your typical restaurant.If you're looking for great pizza, a great environment, and a really fair price, you should go check out this place!

12.description: I love the crust and I absolutely love the amount of cheese that is given. But when I order I normally get 2 or 3 toppings, but when I get toppings here I feel like they are near absent. I recently ordered a pizza with peppers bacon and spinach and it was only present around the edge. The only thing that saved the day was the amount of cheese I was given

59.description: Had ordered from here a few times and was satisfied enough, but never again.  If you like to wait almost an hour and  a half for a cold, chewy pizza delivered by a surly woman who claims she doesn't even work for Bartoli's - this is the place for you!  As for me, there is no shortage of pizza places in Chicago to risk trying this place again.

21.description: The Deep Dish Chicago Classic was featured on Windy City Live.  It looked good and they all seemed to like it.  Steve Dolinsky, The Hungry Hound was on the show and talked about his pizza quest, where he ate  pizza at 75 pizzerias in Chicago and the Suburbs.  Bartoli's was one one of his favorites.   The restaurant has a small dining room. Very casual.  The food is served on paper plates with plastic silverware.   We shared a Caesar Salad with homemade croutons.  Fresh and good.  We also shared the 12" Deep Dish Chicago Classic--sausage, green pepper, onion and mushroom.  One of the best Deep Dish I ever had and very good warmed in the oven the next day.   The crust was tasty with just the right amount of crunch, the toppings were fresh, good sausage and a great pizza sauce. Our children ordered a thin crust pepperoni.  I tasted a slice and it was really good.  The pepperoni was a little spicy, and a good balance off the slightly sweet sauce and cheese. The thin cracker crust is exactly how I like my thin crust pizza.  It's BYOB.  We had fountain drinks.  Free refills.  You help yourself.Orders are placed at the counter.  Staff was friendly and happy to answer questions.

17.description: Bartoli's is a neighborhood staple. Very good pizza, extensive menu and friendly staff. Top menu pick: the badger-style fried cheese balls. Fiance likes the Italian beef sandwich. We tend to switch around our pizza places frequently, but I can't stay away from the cheese balls.  As for Bartoli's pizza - it's good. The deep dish doesn't trump Lou Malnati's though, so I'll pick theirs every time if I'm not in a hurry. From Bartoli's I prefer the thin crust.

10.description: While i was looking forward to trying a new good thin-crust spot, this place really disappointed. The crust was bland, and the sauce was mediocre. I would take a frozen home run inn pizza over this any day of the week.

5.description: Excellent thin crust pizza. The sauce had the right amount of spice and the crust was crispy. Their meatballs are suppose to be amazing so they are next on the list. The owner and staff were genuinely friendly. We will be regulars here

3.description: We are always looking for a good pizza place. My boyfriend though their Rosemary lemon and onion chicken wings were good. The pizza was decent too. The crust was very crispy and I only wish the sauce had more flavor.

35.description: Bartolis is now my #1 for pizza. My favorite pizza is the deep dish with sausage and green peppers. The crust is buttery and crispy. The sauce is a little on the sweet side but amazing. It's even great the second day.

19.description: We have now been to Bartoli's twice, and each time I have been astounded that I have now found a deep dish pizza that I like better than Lou's.  Our first visit was with a group and we had their wings which were really excellent.  We also had a thin crust pizza and a deep dish.  The thin crust was really good and the deep dish is good beyond description.  What is so great about it?  First of all, the crust. Many deep dish pizzas tend to be soggy on the bottom and overly bready and heavy on the top.  Not at Bartoli's!  The bottom was thin and well cooked, and the top of the crust was like eating a piece of freshly baked thin bread.  With some deep dish pizzas I will leave the top crust behind; with Bartoli's, I inhaled it.  Second, the sauce.  It's not too thick yet not runny, just the right consistency.  It is a great combination of sweetness and spiciness, and goes really well with the crust.  Third of course is the cheese.  It's a really nice tasting cheese mixture that seems to pull everything together.  Just the right amount also; not oozing with cheese, but not leaving you feel like "where is the cheese?".  On our second visit we had a large deep dish with sausage and onion.  It was absolutely fabulous!  As other reviewers have mentioned, this is a BYOB.  They do have a bottle opener/corkscrew and some plastic cups available but if you want more fancy glassware, that should be BYO also.  They seem to do a very healthy carryout and delivery business, and the dining room is pleasant, but fairly small.  Both of our experiences were dining in the restaurant as the pizza came right out of the oven.  I have no knowledge of how well the pizza translates when picked up or delivered.  I know that they encourage people who order for pickup or delivery to get the pizza uncut to try and preserve the crispness of the bottom crust.   The owner, Brian, stopped at our table and chatted for a while.  Really nice guy, and related to the founder of Gino's.  This pizza is not a Gino's knockoff, rather it is something that Brian has created through testing and experimentation.  I'm sure his pizza genealogy has helped him in creating a wonderful product.   Give this place a try, it's worth a drive.

28.description: I ordered (for delivery) a deep dish pizza with spinach and pepperoni, but the pizza that arrived was so soggy that I actually poured liquid out of the box before attempting to take a slice. After removing a soggy slice, I noticed the cardboard underneath was almost entirely soaked through, and a few minutes later it had completely soaked through the whole bottom of the box. I tried to eat a few slices, but the only part that was edible was the crust. Maybe this pizza would have been delicious in the restaurant, but I definitely would not recommend ordering a deep dish pizza from Bartoli's for delivery. (And I have a lot of experience ordering deep dish for delivery!)

45.description: Bartoli's is a quick medium sized pizza place a couple miles west of Wrigley Field off of Addison. It is within walking distance from the Brown line. (This is where I was coming from and stopped by here) There is also a westbound Addison bus stop just across the street. Service here was friendly and prompt. I simply got a slice of pizza in an individual to go box and I was waiting for the bus a minute later. The pizza was good and again quick and convenient. It was not that busy but it was clean and seemed orderly. They have a television and seating for those who would like to eat their slice there.

33.description: Excellent thin crust pizza! I love getting the Chicago classic and substituting with pepperoni.  Delivery is always fast and friendly and pick up service is just as easy.  I'm so happy this place is close to my house I order once a week!

43.description: Slices of thin crust pizza are great. Deep dish--meh. All dough and way too much sauce, hardly any cheese. I'll stick with thin crust.Burgers are good, but they're stingy with the amount of fries (which are extra).

2.description: For a slice-on-the-go type of place, their dining room is probably one of the more homely feeling, though warm and comfortable.  I've grabbed slices and relaxed a bit before heading back on the road.  I didn't feel rushed or pushed out the door.  Alike the feeling of the environment so is their approach to serving their customer.  At least in my few experiences. Their pizza is hearty and rich in flavor.  I'm not sure which of their pizzas I appreciate most, whether deep or thin.  But it's tasty and I dig the price.  I've always ordered slices and never had the chance (yet) to order full pies. I feel as though because of that reason I've navigated away from the possibilities of soggy slices. Which can happen with deep dish pies. If ordering a slice there, sometimes I might request a well done slice. I the crunch of the crust.

18.description: Checked out Bartoli's with my wife and 10 year old son along with his friend.  While we waited for the stuffed pizza, ordered some hot wings.  Too hot for the kids but I certainly enjoyed them.  The Spinach pizza we ordered was delicious.  A healthy amount of spinach and the crust was cooked to perfection.  Casual atmosphere and attentive staff in the quaint eating area.  Even the owner came out to see how we were enjoying the food.

41.description: Deep dish = amazing. Wings = okay. Cannoli = phenomenal. I give this place 5 stars despite the okay wings (not bad, just not great... But to be fair, I'm from Buffalo so I'm really picky). The pizza and cannoli are just that good. Will be a repeat customer!

52.description: I really like the manager! Super personable! Pizza is still fabulous. Hooked!

50.description: Ordered a thin crust pepperoni, a deep dish spinach and cheese (added chicken) and a ceasar salad. Everything was delicious and the deep dish was exactly what I was craving while in Chicago. It was more of a cornmeal crust, which I prefer over a flaky dough-y crust. Beware delivery can take a while, especially if you order the deep dish. Totally worth it though!

4.description: I ordered for pickup for my wife and I and it was fantastic!! First time in the restaurant (had some pizza at a Roscoe Village street fest prior) and I was blown away by how clean and modern it was. The deep dish spinach and sausage pizza was incredible as was their SW chicken salad. Can't wait to get back there.

6.description: I got "Bartoli's Chicago Classic" which has Italian sausage, mushroom, onions and green peppers. Deep dish is a must if you're in Chicago and this place is definitely one of the top deep dishes I've ever had. Service and environment was great and friendly. I would recommend this place, you won't be disappointed!!

22.description: Chicago classic deep dish is the way to go.  One of the best in the city.

15.description: Great deep dish delivered,  the wings were ok, not what I expected, will see how everything reheats, but has my pick as great deep dish that CAN BE DELIVERED and will hold up, new go to vs pequads for sure. Lastly, I tried it based on Chicago Magazine's rating of #9 out of 38 and recommend as well

57.description: Excellent customer service. Great food. Pizza is delicious, we also love the badger style cheese balls.

20.description: I'd give this place. 3.5 is I could. Decided to try the deep dish based on the fact it was rate #1 by Steve, the food hound.  Google best deep dish pizza Chicago and look for the list by Steve D from channel 7, I believe. Ordered a medium half pepperoni red paper and 1/2 cheese deep dish along with the lemon garlic wings.  Quote 80 minutes delivery, and it was here in 40 minutes, still warm. Impressive. Wings were good. Nice and charred. Pizza was decent. Nice consistency between crust, cheese and sauce ( although I could have used a little kre sauce). Perfectly crispy.  Good ratio of toppings. Enjoyed it, but I still prefer Art of Pizza for deep dish. Their sauce is a bit sweeter. Nothing wrong with this one, just a personal preference.  Will definitely order apps and a thin crust from here in the future.

36.description: One word: AMAZING. After biking 24 miles in the city, we needed to end the city right and enjoy some Chicago deep dish. We wanted to try something new and Bertoli's was close by. We got a deep dish AND a thin crust. Both so tasty, sauce is so delicious and spinach and sausage was so great. Fresh basil too on margarita pizza. I would 100% recommend this. You can order out or dine in! It's small and cute inside and was a perfect dinner, if not better than Lou Malnatis or any other pizza place. This place was truly out of this world. So fresh and affordable.

14.description: I ordered from Bartoli's twice. After the first experience, I was excited. When I've ordered deep dish previously in Chicago, I tend to get soggy crusts with a lot of excess moisture on the top. My first pizza from Bartoli's couldn't have been more different. There wasn't any excess water/etc to be seen, and the crust was delicious and crispy.When I had family in town a couple weeks later, I wanted to treat them to some great deep dish, so I immediately opted for Bartoli's. Unfortunately, as soon as it arrived, I could tell this was a different experience. The delivery driver wasn't very careful with the pizza and all of the toppings had shifted to one half. There were pools of liquid all over the top of the pizza, and the box was just as soggy as the crust. I called to complain, but received nothing more than a weak I'm sorry. To their credit, they did offer to make a new one, but as I had hungry guests, waiting more than an hour for another pizza isn't quite appealing.I had thought I'd found my new go-to pizza place, but it appears I'll need to keep looking.

1.description: Meh describes it pretty well.  I've had mostly good experiences at this store, but today's wasn't one of them.  I went to this one because they have a parking lot...and I had my car running some errands.  I also remembered I was out of preworkout, so I needed to make a stop.The guy working asked what I came in for, I told him...and he tells me it isn't a good product and is too expensive, but that I should buy this other one that is less expensive and is a GNC brand product.  He was persistent that I should try their product instead of the one that I went there for.  I told him that I'd buy what I came in for, or I'd go somewhere else and get it.  Not a good selling process.  I used to be a sales trainer, and it drives me nuts when sales people ignore what their customer is saying.  I was planning on trying some additional products today, but I opted to get the stuff that I was out of and get out of there.  Other times at this store, it has been good.  I'm a fairly educated consumer, so when I shop, the main question that I ask is the location of a specific product.  I can be persuaded by some add on sales occasionally, but the main products I use, I buy for specific reasons.  Some of the other employees are pretty good.  I'm an easy enough customer, I know what I want, and if you have it-I will spend my money, and often in stock up size/quantities.  Very minimal brain power needed.  However, the pushy side of things drives me out.

2.description: I had the worst experience today at this store. The people were unhelpful and rude. They did not know what they were talking about and plus their prices for products were ridculous! They had talked to me with an attitude and didn't seem to care for my business. I would not recommend anyone to shop or even stop by this store. STAY AWAY,

0.description: I just dropped by to see what vitamins I could buy.  I bought a huge bottle of Fenugreek for $16!  I had been buying a bottle half the size and double the cost from somewhere else.   I was very pleased. The worker was very nice and helpful and gave me a lot of free samples!  I will go back to this GNC for sure!

58.description: I must say this is probably one of the cheapest thrift stores in Chicago - cheaper than Salvation Army for sure.It is not organized by size, kind of separated by color, and somewhat arranged by type of clothing.  There are different sections for "better" clothing, labeled as such.  However, I found an awesome top by Laundry back in with the regular duds, and for $2.50.Tons and tons of jeans, had I wanted to spend more time there, I would have surely picked out a pair.  And even though it's close to Wrigleyville, I still managed to find some Cubbie kids t-shirts, a requisite item on all of my thrift store trips if I can at all help it.Basically there's so much clothes, and what you find definitely depends on how much time you want to spend weeding through the piles.  Someone brought an infant there (probably not a week old), and that kid will have one strong immune system when he rows up.  Cause that place is pretty dirty.

56.description: This is decent place to come and get bargain clothing. I must admit though for guys, it seems pretty hit or miss, and I haven't really found anything here in my last couple of visits. Racks and Racks of women and kids clothing, little bit smaller for men's. Smells like a vintage shop and they store seems to be managed relatively well.

29.description: This is one of my favorite thrift stores ever. I like this location better than the Milwaukee one, even though it's further away for me. Those little ladies are good at keeping aisles clean and racks "organized". To me, it's easier to search for things here. I usually brace myself before entering, pack a snack, and tell my family my whereabouts because sometimes I find myself in here for hours...digging and searching for that needle in the haystack...Prices are way cheaper than Unique, but still not the cheapest I've been to. Although it definitely makes it up in overall cleanliness and quality of items. A couple tips: go downstairs first, and then take your picks upstairs because there's no way to get your cart down those steps (I don't think there's an elevator). Look for clothes by the mirror (sometimes there's cute things left over that don't fit someone who also has good style). Bring headphones (unless you're into Spanish and Shania Twain), and free parking lot just down the street (don't pay for the meter, you may be in here a while)

42.description: Summary for those too lazy to read the rest of the reviews:+Cheap stuff-Crowded-Really dirty-Tons of gross stuff

23.description: Shopping every six months for your kid because he has grown another size can be daunting and rough on the budget. This is where the Village Discount steps in and saves the day. I was able to purchase 24 items for a measly $50.00 flat. Not bad, not bad at all. Spring/Summer here we come...Enjoy Suckas'!!!

47.description: Sometimes there is beauty in chaos. Village Discount is an example of this phenomenon! I will not lie. Yes, some clothes are dirty. Yes, some of the clothes are thrown on the floor. Yes, the shoe section smells terrible. Yes, sometimes you see a shirt and wonder who really wears this! Yes, sometimes it feels like a surrealistic experience. However, if you are patient and if you are highly perceptive, and if you have time, you are rewarded in the end. They have really nice clothes from nice brands. I got a GUESS dress for 1$, another Diana von Vurtenberg dress for 3$ (both of these are supposed to be around 400$).  I got many other items, such as shirts or skirts from BCBG, Tommy, Ralph Lauren, GAP etc. I got my whole tennis outfit from this store also :) Besides the brands, I just find really interesting things there. It is like treasure hunting :) I find Village Discount much better and more fun than a regular store, which has only a few kinds of skirts or shirts and only follow the fashion of that given season. There is just more choice in Village Outlet. It is also significantly cheaper than other "used" stores, which tend to sell items for 10 or 20$. As you can tell, I am a fan!

8.description: You can't beat the treasures, variety or prices of this place.One of the fastest stocked thrift stores in Chicago. It also has great finds, and usually has some kind of sale. I always walk out with good stuff and a heavy bag for under $10 of stuff.My go-to thrift store.

31.description: I'm a second-hand Rose, so to speak, and second hand clothes don't tend to freak me out.  Almost everything I wear is pre-owned.  So, I didn't think I would be in for much of a surprise with Village.  Didn't seem my speed - I tend toward labels simply because they are better made than the Made in China stuff I saw here, and the place made me long for a shower.   However, I did see a huge selection of woven baskets for supercheap, and I went a bit nuts.  I grabbed five baskets, all under $3 each, and headed to the checkout.  The price of one of the baskets (the best one) wasn't marked.  I was told that the manager had to price it and I had to come back the next day.  Now, I'm pretty savvy about ghetto stores - you know, no dressing rooms, checking my bag at the front, etc.  But I've never heard of anything like this.  I spoke with the manager, and told him I'd pay $10 for the basket on the spot - 5x more than the other baskets.  No dice.  He gave me a hold slip, and told me to come back the next day.I returned the next day (and had to chase off the boot guy when I walked the wrong way out of the parking lot) and they still hadn't priced the basket.  So, the manager priced it on the fly (REALLY???  I thought they had to do some overnight research, make some calls to an archaeologist or carbon date it or something) and guess what...they charged me $3.80.  Yes, I paid less than what I offered, but what utter crap.  It's not my fault the basket wasn't priced.  I'm clearly not trying to rip anyone off, and they would have made three times as much if they had simply taken my offer the first time.

34.description: This is one of my favorite thrift stores in Chicago. I've been to most of the Village Discounts. Like most thrift stores, they can vary quite a bit. This one is well-organized and has less of an "ick" factor than a lot of the cheaper places, like Goodwill and Salvation Army.I wandered in last winter and found a nice coat. Then today, I found a cute dress for summer while at the Retro on Roscoe festival. Quite a bargain for around $3. No where else on the streets in this area can you find a $3 dress. Unlike trendier fare, this place is much more reasonably priced and has a great variety of real-people sized clothing.

16.description: This can be a great thrift store, HOWEVER, BEWARE OF THEIR PRIVATE PARKING LOT. I know parking can be hard to come by in Roscoe Village...but if you can, try to avoid parking in their parking lot. If you do, be warned: there appears to be some sort of scam operation going on there. Recently, on two seperate occasions, with two seperate cars, my fiance and I had our cars messed with while parked in this lot. In his case: his hubcabs were stolen from one side of his vehicle. In the middle of the day! In my case: I had a small pouch, that I used for organizing coupons, etc., stolen from front seat. I assume whoever broke into my car thought this pouch was actually a wallet. My car was definitely locked, and this also occured in the middle of the day. I tried contacting the police, to file a complaint, but since this is private property, there is nothing they can do. What upsets me most is that the theives targeting this parking lot are stealing from people who obviously don't have a lot of extra money to spare-which is why they're shopping at a THRIFT STORE! Thrift store iteslf: 4 stars. Sometimes I find really cute, interesting stuff here.Private parking lot experiences: 0 stars.

13.description: It's no coincidence that "VDO" sounds like a disease.All this store needs is:- staff who can speak English, any at all- either wider aisles or no shopping carts (the current combo is disastrous)- fewer items shoved onto racks to prevent the wretched spillage- worthy goods that are not stained, broken, or tornThrift stores are typically great for making gently-used goods available to lower-income folks, but VDO is a flat-out insult to humanity. Their items aren't worth the construction paper "price tags" stapled onto them. I am now taking bets on how much longer this grungy business will occupy so much prime real estate before being flipped to something more suitably bougie for Roscoe retail row.

11.description: This place is what a thrift store should be- cheap and filled with inventory. They have just enough staff to keep someone at the register while everyone else sorts inventory, which keeps prices low. They have a parking lot, which is a treat in Chicago. They lose one star for having narrow aisles AND shopping carts, but the crowding is all part of maximizing the amount of inventory available. It was clean enough for a thrift store.Do check out the basement. All sorts of treasures await!

39.description: Pleasantly happy with this store. I found a few crazy glittery purses, a ridiculous Halloween vase and a cool basket ...all for a mere $14. My only complaint was that were only two cashiers, the place was pretty busy and the wait in line almost killed me. I think it was about 20 min. There was only one person in front of me! (She had like 100 bed linens. Seriously? Do you really need that many *used* sheets / blankets etc.???)  Other than the excruciating wait and the slow, taking-her-sweet- ass-time cashier, it was a pretty decent store.

37.description: Went here the other day with my friends, honestly I haven't been since high school when I used to buy little boy tshirts to wear because it was cool.It was just as I remembered it, smelled a bit (its a thrift store) but it was huge. Things were decently organized (color scheme) and the prices were dirt cheap. I found a leather bag for $3 that I have been using everyday since! (Plus whoever donated it left some $ in it... sweet!)I'd recommend going to the VD if you have some time on your hands or know what you are looking for. This place is big, and it takes some digging to find treasures, but I can assure you there is treasure in this place.

0.description: Like other people have said, if you have time and patience, you can find some real treasures here.  I like to come early in the morning on a holiday weekend because EVERYTHING is half off.   I've seen bar mirrors, some high end cookware, and some very nice clothing here.  I was able to outfit myself with maternity clothes the whole time I was pregnant from this location for about $50, whereas just a new maternity business skirt would have cost about that much. I took off a star because most of the staff is honestly not so great.  There are a few nice folks working here, but a lot of them are just "point and grunt" types. This really isn't surprising; I'm sure they're getting paid very well.

38.description: Best advantage about this place imparticular to all other village discounts: their basement!!! Shoes, and other goodies a plenty!If you can handle the little children of bad parents running everywhere and are prepared to be there for about an hour minimum looking through goods, then you will be FINE!

51.description: Many of the racks are neatly arranged according to color and general style (button-down, long-sleeve, sweater...) That's always appreciated.I was perplexed by the apparent lack of dresses at this location. My friend said maybe they rotate them out of the floor since not many people want exposed legs in freezing temperatures. I'm not sure about that; there are still occasions for dressing up even when it's cold.Many of the shoes had caked-on mud. I would hope they'd at least whack the shoes on something to break some of it off.I got two pairs of nice (Calvin Klein, etc.) corduroys and a pair of jeans for under $10 total. And they all fit me when I tried them on at home. Score!I guess that's a good summary of the ups and downs of thrift store shopping.

27.description: Be wary of patronizing a store that hires a very sleazy booting company (Global Parking Mgmt) to patrol their lot and boot their customers cars.  They obviously make a cut of the $115 it will cost you to get the boot off.

32.description: This is my favorite VDO! I've shopped a lot of Villages and i enjoy this one the best. I stumbled upon here after a friend told me about it.1. It's in the cute kitchy roscoe village which is my favorite area in chicago. 2. The service here is mostly better than most villages I've shopped at ( i live near the Kimball one and this one has better service). This one is great. 3. They have a good shoe/book/Jewelry section. 4. They clean and more organized. 5. The old man who works the register was very friendly and priced something for me on the spot and sold it to me for a quarter. 6. The clothing selection is amazing here. I've gotten so much great stuff here on half off day sales, on top of it, they have great home decore stuff i got a whole lot of vintage plates for 3.00  and i've found some amazing jewelry pieces here. 7. It's in a quiet location and has to be my absolute favorite in chicago. this is the best village discount there is.

54.description: YES! I have only been to this VDOil (that is there website address!) anyhoo. I found a great homemade green jumpsuit, some topnotch lime green fabric to sew with and some other stuff that rocked my world. My girl Alex found top quality 1960's Italian heels. Wahoo! I would sure like to make it back here again soon.

48.description: VDO weekly specials for the week of April 13, 2009:1. used stringy/shredded loofah = $0.802. a hole-in-the-crotch used pantyhose = $1.003. worn underwear individually priced at $0.894. sweat stained baseball cap = $1.895. 2 individual shoulder pads ripped from an 80's blazer safety pinned together as a set = $0.50...and as an added bonus, a huge dried up "mystery" spill on aisle 18!'nuff said.

44.description: I live a block away, so I tried this place out.  All I wanted was a baking dish and a decent sweater.  Couldn't find either. Not a great selection. Definitely lower quality clothes than the Salvation Army, but they are also a bit cheaper.  It was well organized but not too clean.  They only have one shelve of dishes, one small shelf of electronics, some jewelry, and clothes. Unless your in the neighborhood, I won't come here.

24.description: worst store ever. went in to store then went next door came out and booted my car for $140. Will never visit  this store again.management should be ashamed of themselves.

7.description: This place had tons of things. Easy to get lost in there. Many things are placed in the wrong sections, so if you go make sure you have plenty of time to look around. Lots of name brand items.

49.description: You know the expression "curiosity killed the cat"?  Well, that saying was made for situations like the one I was in this afternoon.  I was wandering down Roscoe, saw this place, and decided to stop in.  Don't get me wrong, I knew it wasn't Bloomies, but I thought they might have a scale (I've decided my bathroom needs a scale and don't want to go to Target as that involves walking under an overpass - EWW!).  So, yeah, curiosity led me into this store where, from the second I entered, I was seriously on edge.  I suppose that makes it "curiosity made the cat want to kill herself" or "curiosity made the cat fear imminent death from a highly-contagious communicable disease", but I digress.Back to our story.  By now, dear reader, you are wondering why I stayed.  Well... they have used books.  Used books are like crack to me.  I'm a total junkie.  Books were marked 25 cents each or 5 for a dollar.  Bargain!  I grabbed two Mary Higgins Clark (can't go wrong with MHC!) and headed to the cash register.The lady in front of me had purchased two large glass vases, in addition to a host of other stuff.  VDO packages its wares in garbage bags for shoppers to take home.  The woman had to have an awkward screaming fight with the cashier to be allowed to wrap her vases so they wouldn't be smashed.  All the while I'm humming to myself and thinking "booksbooksbooksbooks".  It will be over soon.  It's my turn.  Mr. Friendly at the cash register announces that my total is "twenty-eight".  Now, I'm no math major, but I'm pretty sure 2 books at 25 cents each does not "twenty-eight" make.  "Twenty-eight cents?" I inquire?  "You want to pay twenty-eight dollars?!"  Mr. Friendly bellows back.  No, dude, I just lack your powers of mathe-magic.  Whatevs.  Give me my books.

40.description: This is my favorite Village Discount Outlet.  Sure you have to breathe through your mouth when you shop in the Bargain Basement,  but it's worth it for the great deals.  I don't know if it's the nice neighborhood or what, but this is the one where I get the best baby clothes, winter hats and toys.  If you are a reader, this store has a HUGE selection of books.  New books, classics, etc.  They are not organized by subject or title, but they are clearly visible on a huge back wall so you can easily browse.    Not much for kids books is the one downfall.I have also found some great art at this store.  I bought a framed painting of three bears and when I got home I googled the artist and found out it was several hundred dollars!  Plus its super cool.  Yeah, I think bears are cool.  The kids do run pretty wild in this store which can be annoying.  And really is not safe for the kids.  Watch out for pickpockets too!  I also like the staff at this store and the management is good about opening new lines when it is busy.  Much appreciated!Check them out on the 50% off days for the best deals.

53.description: Does it smell?????? yesIs it cramped?????? yesCrying kids??????? yesIs it warm???????? yesStressful???????? yesWhenever I go to a thrift store I rush through it to find exactly what I want. Quite similar to a game, and never do I win.The smell just makes me move faster with more passion.I did find some sweet things here like a bosca wallet.

30.description: I like this place.Sure, the aisles are teeny and it's hard to squish by other people, it may smell a bit, and the clothes are organized by color, but you can get some great stuff here.The only time I've ventured into the clothing section was to pick out chunky cable knit sweaters I was cutting up to make pillow slipcovers. Total cost: less than $10 for 6 slipcovers. Take that Pottery Barn!Usually, I only visit a few sections - the vase/plate section, the book section, and the housewares section.Some recent scores:1. Williams-Sonoma alphabet cookie cutters still sealed in their original tin: $22. Original pyrex mini-bowl: $0.40 (for some strange reason, vintage pyrex bowls cost a fortune on ebay and in antique shops)3. 4 new paperback books: .$.80 (includes NY Times Best Sellers from a couple months ago)4. Vintage stocking (the knitted kind): $0.45I look in the back at the blankets too. Sure there are some old, gross looking comforters, but sometimes, you'll find absolutely gorgeous handmade afghans for less than $8.Check out the plates. They are all from our grandparents' time and some of the stuff is gorgeous. I'm pretty convinced I've seen real silver pieces there too. I have a thing for vintage pyrex bowls, and I've seen quite a few pieces here.I love browsing here once a month or so to find new treasures. I always leave with a stack of books. It's a cheap way to keep my reading habit going.Oh, and my husband was able to put together a Prince William costume last Halloween from stuff purchased here for only $8. Red coat and all!If you hate digging, you'll hate this place. But, if you have some time to kill or want to indulge your book-collecting habit, this is where you should go.

46.description: Reminded me a lot of Unique thrift stores. This store had a lot of stuff, but I ended up buying one flannel shirt for 83 cents (not bad for an awesome oversized shirt) because it was 1/2 price tag day. My two friends left with huge bags full of clothes for very cheap. The bargain basement is a little scary, but there were tons of shoes and kids clothing.3 stars for how cheap it was, its convenient location, and amount of clothing. Not the best thrift store I've been to, but very comparable to Unique.

1.description: I had one of the most annoying experiences at VDO last night that I had to write this review. After searching for a halloween outfit (black skirt, grey top) I bring my two items to check out. The skirt, which I had to spend plenty of time to find in the right size and look, did not have a tag on it. The check-out clerk told me she couldn't sell merchandise without a tag...while smiling at me! I asked her if she was joking, since the smile was a bit confusing, and she continued to say no she could not sell it without a tag. I was then told I had to put it on hold and pick it up tomorrow. After asking why it couldn't just be priced right now...at least three times with no clear response....a 'manager' walks over and says only the morning management prices merchandise. Why in the world would only a morning manager have the ability to write a number on a piece of paper is beyond me! So after fuming over the fact that two store workers were unable to put a damn price on the skirt and let me leave with it I decide, fine...I will put it on hold. But wait!! When I say I will just hold the shirt and skirt together to pick up both tomorrow..she smiles at me and says they do not hold tagged merchandise!! So now I can not purchase one item because it does not have a tag..their fault not mine...and I can not hold the other one because it DOES have a tag! After my experience I would say don't waste your time searching for items in this store only to finally find them and be put through the crap I was for no good reason.

55.description: This place stresses me out. Every once in a while, I think, "hey, I'm going to stroll over to Village Discount and spend a leisurely late afternoon poking through the racks, where undoubtedly I'll find the coolest, cheapest, thriftiest clothes imaginable. People will ask me where I got that badass jacket/bag/pair of jeans, and I'll say airily, 'oh, it was like two bucks at Village Discount.'"I get about halfway down the first aisle of women's clothing, and start to feel like I'm suffocating. I'll half-heartedly zig-zag through the aisles and make a pass at the housewares. With all my resolve gone, and the smell of unwashed clothing and floors strangling me, I'll loop through the men's section, then bolt for the door. I wish I liked this place. I really do. But Brown Elephant on Halsted is a lot cleaner, a lot airier, and has a much better selection of housewares and clothing. To Village Discount's credit, though, their selection of kids' clothing is banging, even though its in the dingy dungeony basement.People who complain about their cars getting booted while they run other errands should 1) heed the signs posted all over the parking lot and 2) walk.

9.description: I love thrift stores, but this place was just plain gross.  It smelled bad.  There was stuff thrown everywhere.  I honestly don't know why people give this place such good reviews.

26.description: Not as organized as the Clark location, but I was still able to find some items on my list. 50%off sale makes the my visit worth it. Overall, W. Roscoe location, Just so-so. I don't see myself coming back to this location.

25.description: Agree w Laurie - I bought a scarf here but because I went next door for take out before they booted my car and issued $140 ticket - so beware and don't use the lot.  I won't give them any repeat business after this.

12.description: This place is a hot mess. We walked in just to check it out, and claustrophobia set in immediately. Probably some stuff to be found here, but I certainly don't have the fortitude to navigate the cramped pathways and many other customers to find it.

59.description: I come here all the time, often consoling myself after having had some crappy ass meal at Kitsch'n, and you can just always find amazing deals without even having to dig too hard. Even if this might be the dirtiest thrift store ever.Their prices are way below a lot of other thrift stores in the area and they just have a truly overwhelming amount of crap in here that is fairly organized, but in a pretty chaotic way, so you really have to be in "thrift sto shopping mode" to truly appreciate it all. The basement is kind of dark, dirty and scary, but they have really good kids clothing down there.Don't even think of keeping your car parked in their lot and grabbing a quick bite to eat - They will certainly boot you and/or tow you and extort great amounts of money from you. You might ask: "How would they know if I just walk over and have a shitty meal at Kitsch'n or a decent but overpricedmeal at Orange?"   How would they know? -  they have been sitting there waiting for you to try that shit all day, just so that they can screw with your whole life, which will all but certainly take the thrill out of  that $2 Michael Stars shirt you found.

21.description: This place is a dump.  Trucks blocking the alley every day, parking boot disputes all of the time in the parking lot, and a nastry store front.  I ventured inside once and the place is dirty and the dock wokers look like they want to kill you.

17.description: Shopping every six months for your kid because he has grown another size can be daunting and rough on the budget. This is where the Village Discount steps in and saves the day. I was able to purchase 24 items for a measly $50.00 flat. Not bad, not bad at all. Spring/Summer here we come...Enjoy Suckas'!!!

10.description: I've lived in this neighborhood for years, and somehow never came to Village Discount.  I love shopping but hate spending money, so after brunch last weekend my friend (an expert thrifter) convinced me to go in and shop around.I'm gonna pop some taaaaaags, only got twenty dollars in my pocket....  And for that $20, I got two sweater dresses ($8 each) and a cardigan ($3).  What a deal!  I'm wearing a sweater dress today and already got compliments on it.This place is kind of a hot mess though.  It's pretty disorganized, signage looks like it hasn't changed in 15 years, confusing nomenclature (cardigans called "open sweaters," dress section seemingly not containing dresses?)  Tons of stuff is hideous, I mean hilariously hideous.  You could have a ball here just scanning the racks for oh-my-god-i-can't-believe-somebody-bought-that sweaters.  Very generally speaking, within a section items are color coded, though this isn't super well-maintained.  I mean obviously the shoppers just toss stuff wherever but I'm not sure if anybody is picking up after them.You can find some amazing deals here.  Nothing high-end (not a consignment store, duh), but some really nice like-new clothes for dirt cheap.  I'm seriously starting to wonder why I'd shop anywhere else, ever.  I mean, the aisles are crowded, and there's the heartbreak of finding something adorable and it doesn't fit.  But oh my gosh, if you get a good deal, it will be a GOOD deal.I only looked in women's clothing, noticed they had bras and swimsuits - so I don't know how I feel about that.  I saw lots of kids jammies and bedspreads too.  For a low-income family or just somebody trying to save cash who needs to get some new clothes for their kids, this would be great.  And this would be a great place to get "ironic" t shirts from somebody else's high school!I did see stuff from Aeropostale, Abercrombie, and New York and Co.  Nothing more high end than that.  But I'm already planning my return!!  What  a great place to revamp your wardrobe for pennies.

5.description: I haven't written a review on thrift stores yet... so this will be my first, here goes!There are lots of great things about this Village Discount Outlet.  I've been thrifting for a long, long time so I feel quite at home browsing through racks upon racks of clothes until my arms get tired.  That being said, this is one of the nicer Village Discounts I've been to.  AMBIANCE:Normally I go to the one on 3301 Lawrence, but this one is "up a notch" in terms of cleanliness, an additional basement level, quantity of clothing and music (they had great variety of music on the speakers... which makes a difference!)Perhaps the feel of this thrift store reflects more of the persona of Roscoe Village/Lakeview.  I'm no local expert on Chicago neighborhoods, but this Village Discount felt more "posh" and would be a place where I'd be completely comfortable taking a friend who needs an introduction to the world of thrifting, without being totally overwhelmed.THE BROWSING EXPERIENCE:To start off, it smelled like Febreeze as I browsed through the aisles.  Woot!  A little air freshener made a huge difference, and the (very normal) grimy feeling I get after touching all the clothes felt... less grimy.  Tis the life of a thrifter.  No biggie.The clothes were neatly hung, grouped in an orderly fashion and they had a large selection of women's blouses and business professional clothing.  I came here specfically looking for work attire, and I did not leave disappointed.  Their selection of collared women's blouses is very large.  (As is their children's clothing section, and their shoe selection which is in the basement)It was difficult to find my size, but I left with a work outfit for less than $4.00! I browsed through most of the women's selection in about an hour.  Again, very clean, very "well-presented"... like a thrift shop on its best behavior.PARKING:There is a private lot just for shoppers West of the building on Roscoe.  On the speakerphones they will routinely announce that you MUST return STRAIGHT to your car after leaving the store or your tires will be booted.  They really do not want people to abuse their parking privileges... but to make it seem less stern, their message is dispersed throughout a playlist of Beyonce, a song in Spanish, a hit from the 80s and a 90s alternative.THE POINT BEING...This place is well kept, clean, has a great selection and a vibe that leans towards that of a department store.  I'm glad I found another thrift shop in Chicagoland and hopefully it will be one of my regular spots.

3.description: Probably one of my favorite thrift stores to go to in Chicago! I always get great deals and their prices are amazing, especially when they have one of their 50% off everything weekends, which is pretty frequent. This is my favorite thrift store for clothing, because they have a huge amount! Not a lot of furniture.Only con is that they don't have dressing rooms, so you just kind of have to guess on clothing.

35.description: This place is my fairy shoe and Fiestaware land.Beyond that, I don't have much else to add. I get good shoes, new shoes and Fiestaware at odd and end times.I collect tacky souvenir plates for my dining room because I'm that kind of girl and they're always overly priced, sometimes as high as the original sticker price...Also the status of orange versus yellow is another issue. They will not budge even when other patrons tell them the color is yellow. I'm not that cheap, but I know what orange is, my house color theme is around the orange palette.So why three? Well, like I said I have found some sweet stuff there and I always end up only spending about 10 dollars on some decorative crap and shoes.,,but the place needs air and for the love of god, get close to orange stickers, if you're going to say orange. It's color theory principle.

19.description: This place is a complete scam. The only reason they are in business is to have their parking lot where they boot people for $140 a clip. If you shop at this place you are hurting the neighborhood.  The last thing an upscale neighborhood like Roscoe Village needs is a thrift shop. I wish these people nothing but the worst and hope they go out of business.

28.description: If you have a lot of time to kill and want a good bargain, stop by the Village Discount Outlet.  I'm sure they're trying quite hard to keep the overwhelming stock in check, but it's a losing proposition.  All that being said, if you have the time, there are fun (and cheap!) treasures to be had!  Wear something that you can try-on over, as I couldn't find a dressing room.  Also, check items quite carefully for holes and stains.

45.description: It's not just messy...I can handle messy. Disorganization and clutter are just part of thrift shopping. But this Village Discount is DIRTY. Questionable spills EVERYWHERE, very difficult to peruse the aisles without stepping into something sticky or goopy every few steps. This one also has more unattended children running amuck than any other store I have been to...crawling around on the icky floors, darting through the aisles, hiding behind racks of clothing (very difficult to sift through the racks without accidentally bumping a small child who has concealed him or herself on the other side of the hanger).While the prices are better (most things in the $1-2 range, not bad), I don't think I can spend more than ten minutes at this one. They did have a wider shoe selection than other stores, so if you must come here, come here for the shoe selection only.

33.description: Enough of the negative reviews already! This is a THRIFT store, not freakin' macys! I found this place to have an impressively large selection of clothes, shoes and  bags. Plus  it's really well-organized and has a lot of attractive long evening dresses. I haven't had much trouble finding a specific style or fit, and the clothes are usually kept in good condition. And you really can't beat the prices! I nearly spent $20 on a whole new wardrobe ; p.

43.description: I'll tell you, folks in the city are spoiled. Having moved out of Chicago a few years ago the Village is one of the things we miss the most. Sure there's "junk" but you're going to find that at a thrift store. They have great prices, they rotate their merchandise and if you're experienced enough to know how to shop a thrift store you'll find considerably better "finds" here then you will most any other place... and having shopped thrift stores for the 30 years we lived there, we've been to them all. In fact when we come back into the city we always try to make sure we stop at the Village. We've not found anything better at those prices outside of the city.

2.description: Village Discount Outlet had the Super Bowl weekend sale on Saturday (01/31/2015) and Sunday (02/01/2015).  All merchandize was half off the price tag.  Hey, I'm in!  As many of you know, thrift shopping on an extra discount day can be adventurous and requires lots of patience.  Thanks to my mommy who gave me a great temperament so that I can survive in thrift shopping.  This location is the first one that I encountered has the "guard" on both entrance and exit, meaning that an entrance is really the entrance; an exit is really the exit.  Those doors aren't interchangeable.  Their private parking lot is strictly for patrons-only; don't follow the rule, should your vehicle be booted and towed immediately.  This location gets lots of young blood since the Lakeview neighborhood is adjacent to the Roscoe Village neighborhood.  It was cool to see some young men and young ladies came out to enjoy themselves with experiencing fashion in different eras.  Shopping at any Village Discount Outlet requires a keen eye.  How keen?  I would say freakin' keen because they organize their apparel by colors.  However, the color-coordinating organizations tend be destroyed quickly by careless customers who didn't put back their unwanted merchandize back to where it belongs.  I don't literally go through "every" piece of apparel myself, but I can spot some possibilities within seconds after seeing them.  I'm professional, so what can I say?  As I have mentioned before on my other reviews on other Village a Discount Outlet locations, their selections on blazers are pretty decent.  However, this location really has one of the worst smells, especially on their basement where shoes, housewares, and electronic gadgets are.  I went downstairs and didn't really stay too long.  I might need to bring my own oxygen mask to shop downstairs, seriously.  I didn't see much $0.10 merchandize left.  We came in late afternoon, so the majority should have been bought during the day.  Other than the smell, this locations seems to get a lot of traffic and aisles are narrow.  I still scored a Cubs beanie for $2 and hubby snatched a cable for his video game monitor for $0.49!  It's a passable location, as long as you're ok with the smell.

18.description: I like this place.Sure, the aisles are teeny and it's hard to squish by other people, it may smell a bit, and the clothes are organized by color, but you can get some great stuff here.The only time I've ventured into the clothing section was to pick out chunky cable knit sweaters I was cutting up to make pillow slipcovers. Total cost: less than $10 for 6 slipcovers. Take that Pottery Barn!Usually, I only visit a few sections - the vase/plate section, the book section, and the housewares section.Some recent scores:1. Williams-Sonoma alphabet cookie cutters still sealed in their original tin: $22. Original pyrex mini-bowl: $0.40 (for some strange reason, vintage pyrex bowls cost a fortune on ebay and in antique shops)3. 4 new paperback books: .$.80 (includes NY Times Best Sellers from a couple months ago)4. Vintage stocking (the knitted kind): $0.45I look in the back at the blankets too. Sure there are some old, gross looking comforters, but sometimes, you'll find absolutely gorgeous handmade afghans for less than $8.Check out the plates. They are all from our grandparents' time and some of the stuff is gorgeous. I'm pretty convinced I've seen real silver pieces there too.
