I've had dry yucca fries before and they know how to make it perfectly here. Sandwiches are pretty big and come with plantain chips (though some of the chips were cold and soggy), but you will be satisfied. I also got the regular Cubana, it was just ok after trying the croquetta. The Cubana just tastes like a regular ham sandwich you can make at home. The croquetta on the other hand was what I was wanting to experience. Great flavor and texture. Something different for my tastebuds, almost like bbq or balsamic vinegar but not too sour, a little sweet. Tasted so good mm. My daughter said, "this is delicious!.. "  Sounding a bit surprised herself. So my suggestion would be to try the other sandwiches

21.description: This is one of my favorite finds on the North side. The restaurant is small, with only enough seats for a handful of people. Don't let that scare you away because the food is amazing.

17.description: Excellent Cuban coffee!

10.description: (Update: this is for the logan square location) I went on a Friday with my boyfriend for dinner. We didn't have a reservation but we're able to find parking and be seated right away even though it was crowded. Atmosphere is great if you want a good time for a group of friends because it is loud - so not a good place for a quiet conversation. It's also BYOB which is nice. We brought a bottle of rum and got the moijito pitcher. Probably not the best moijito only because I don't consider myself a bartender so maybe the portions were off, but still very tasty.For an appetizer we got empanadas which you order in 3s. We ordered spinach, chicken, and chorizo/goat cheese. All were delicious and a good amount of filling with a flaky pastry crust that tastes homemade. For an entree we got bistec de palomilla which comes with white rice and beans and cooked plaintains, a typical cuban dinner. The steak was thin cut and flavorful but I would probably get something different next time because it had too many onions for my liking which overpowered the steak.Overall, it was a pleasant experience and our waitress was very nice and friendly. I would like to try it again during the summer when there is outdoor seating available.

5.description: Stopped here for a quick bite.  The quirky wall paper reminded me of the Cuba -US historical relationship, but transported me to an earlier time.  The space may feel like a hole-in-the-wall, but the flavors make up for what is lacks in space.  I had the Ropa Vieja ( shredded beef) sandwich and was in heaven!  Authentic flavors, not pretentious, humble but surprising!  I'll be back!

3.description: I am in LOVE with 90 Miles Cuban Cafe! I had no idea I'd find a vegan-friendly Cuban place and this was certainly a surprise.  The tofu dish--made with tofu, pepper, and onion simmered in creole sauce and white wine--was to die for!  It was obvious that time and care was put into the preparation of this food because it was just phenomenal.This is also a great place for vegans and non-vegans to dine together as there are options for everyone.  My boyfriend loved the meat dish he ordered too.

35.description: I lived in South Florida for 12 years. I loved the Cuban cuisine and have missed it for almost 6 years.  I searched Chicago for a quality reviewed CUBAN (not Mexican) restaurant because I craved Masas de Puerco. This meal was phenomenal. The sweet plantains were so juicy and sweet. Two wedges of fresh lime for the fried pork chunks was the perfect amount to have a nice flavor of tropical lime.  I'm so pleased with my experience with this restaurant. I will be coming back.  Thank you for being so wonderful!!

19.description: This is a fabulous little spot serving the best Cuban fare around.  It's an interesting concept that fits very well into this establishment's name, 90 Miles Cuban Cafe.The lechon I had was excellent as was the Cuban sandwich on another visit. It was equally as good.  The French fries and fried plantain chips are great too!  This place can be hoping....... Improve your customer service!   ... Looks like  you have plenty of help, step out from the back counter and be a tad more accomodating to your patrons.  Maybe some colorful tablecloths outside in summer would surely draw attention and bring more people in.   Action and people bring more people!On the two occasions I was there, the food was fantastic but it was dead.  Do something positive to bring more people in. Walk outside and ask people how's it going.  Refill their drinks but step out from behind the counter.  You're not White Castle's, you have to work harder!I ll be back ... I want you to earn that 5th star!

28.description: Solid food and fun scene. Long wait but a good place to go with friends for drinks and dinner. Had my birthday celebration there and all enjoyed.

45.description: This is a very small location which I think of mostly to go.... The sitting is very limited however the food is great!!! I've had the ropa vieja and the cubano sandwiches and they never disappoint me. I always get the cafe con leche here as well since they make it right then and there. Service could be a little bit friendlier but that doesn't stop me from coming back!! Lol Definitely recommend it to anyone in the area looking for a good Cuban sandwich!

33.description: Amazing food and reasonable price!  Place is down the street from where I live/work and it always hits the spot!

43.description: the time it took to get my sammie was a little crazy-a cubano and it was 20 minutes until i had it in my hand togo? seems too long.  The sandwich was delicious though! I can't wait to try other sandwiches with more sauce.  I'll definitely be going back.

2.description: This place never disappoints. As a proud Puerto Rican, I lay claim to having the best tostones, but I have to ignore the crispy, tender, salty snacks at 90 Miles. No matter, Cubans can fry a plantain like the best of us. From the media noche to the bistec de palomilla, everything is seasoned to my liking and fresh. Cafe con leche is on point with flavor, even though I could do with less sugar sometimes. This location is counter service with some sweet and savory empanadas to carry out. Either check out the daily lunch sandwich specials above the water jug (available until 5pm) or ask for a full menu. At all hours I've found the cashier to be willing to make recommendations. Grab one of the few stools inside and the cashier will bring your dinner to you. If you don't order a drink they have plastic cups and a water jug for you to help yourself.It can get really crowded during colder months since there are so few seats in this corner lot space. They offer delivery and carryout if you'd prefer to eat at home. Heck, you could even sit in your car in their lot if you didn't want to wait. I wouldn't judge.Before you go: I recommend the masitas de puerco appetizer. It's magically crispy on the outside and super tender and juicy inside. Plus, fried pork.

18.description: This is a very small location which I think of mostly to go.... The sitting is very limited however the food is great!!! I've had the ropa vieja and the cubano sandwiches and they never disappoint me. I always get the cafe con leche here as well since they make it right then and there. Service could be a little bit friendlier but that doesn't stop me from coming back!! Lol Definitely recommend it to anyone in the area looking for a good Cuban sandwich!

41.description: What a pleasant surprise.  We stopped in for cortaditos and had some maduros as well.  I enjoyed everything and thought the food was fabulous.  Service was friendly and great - look forward to returning.

52.description: COME ON, SHAKE YOUR BODY BABY, DO THE CONGA!I was introduced to this place by my 20-something year old niece. She really knows a lot of great restaurants in the city! We've been here several times over the years. My favorite dish is the Churrasco which is marinated skirt steak and super tender. It is served with garlic sauce, a little parsley, yellow rice and boiled yuca (which is like a potato) con mojo de ajo. If you do not like garlic do not order this dish. My husband always orders the Fricase de pollo which is perfectly prepared with an goluptious of flavors and fall off the bone tender. The vibe is cool with people of all ages. When we came here, I heard the song, "Come on, Shake Your Body Baby, Do the Conga!" I started tapping my foot to the beat of the music. Hey, after a few drinks I really wanted to start a Conga line, but I was afraid I'd get kicked out of the restaurant. Maybe next time I'll get the courage to actually start a Conga line! Oh, but I digress....back to the food....For starters, we ordered the empanadas (three different kinds) -- chicken, ropa vieja and beef. They don't tell you which one is which so you have to bite into them to find out "which" one is chicken, beef or ropa vieja. We shared the stuffed papa which was perfectly prepared and very, very good. Empanadas are worthy of 4 stars. The stuffed potatoes are 5 stars worthy. To be perfectly honest, I have had much better Cuban comida (food) at other Cuban restaurants in Chicago (for a lot less). Give "El Cubanito" in Logan Square a shot (OMFG, I love their steak and Cuban sandwiches). Also, hit up "Paladar" (Western Ave) or even "Señor Pan (on North Ave, near Western) for tasty Cuban comida. Señor Pan has two locations, but I prefer their North Ave joint. La comida at these places is actually much more delectable with higher quality cuts of meat than here. You're welcome for these tips! We usually bring two bottles of wine. We enjoy Argentinian wines, such as, Malbec or Tempranillo, both pair nicely with meat dishes. Go here early (even if you don't usually eat an early dinner), especially on weekends. We brought along two bottles of Bodegas Graffigna 2012 Centenario Malbec, but any Malbec wine balances nicely with meat dishes. Service is effusive, but incredibly lackadaisical. On weekends, it gets super crazy crowded for dinner. I recommend trying this joint for lunch instead. The wait can be crazy long for dinner service, especially on weekends. It is a small restaurant with indoor and outdoor seating. It can also get very polyphloisboisterous inside! You may wait up to 30-minutes for your comida, so definitely pop open your bottle of vino and order several appetizers to avoid passing out at your table. The food is flavorful with various Latin herbs and spices. Portions are fine, but not huge. This is a great place for people of all ages (great for small groups, not large). The outdoor seating fills up quickly in the Summer. Hey, if you do not mind inhaling gas fumes while enjoying your meal then sit outside, by all means!  Parking around here can be a pain in the ass. The inside is really dated. Nothing spectacular. The decor is rather tired, dark, dingy and boring. Service -- 3 stars (at a turtle's pace)Price-point -- 4 starsCuisine -- 4 starsAmbiance/Decor -- 3 starsOutdoor patio -- 2 stars (please invest in new tables/chairs)For the best Cuban sandwiches hit up "El Cubanito" or "Paladar" (definitely get the Ropa Vieja here). Also, Cohiba Cuban Cuisine (Broadway, east side, half block north of Diversey) serves outstanding ropa vieja. El Paladar and Cohiba are great spots for a date night with your spouse or for a "First" date. Also, give Señor Pan a shot -- really good spot for lunch or dinner (North Ave location). If you are seeking exceptional and delectable Puerto Rican cuisine, hit up Casa Yari, Juanita's or La Plena. (Read the Yelp reviews if you don't believe me)!

50.description: Yummmmmm, I would have given 5 stars but I've had several bad experiences with some of their dishes. This establishment is still on my top list of weekend choices however. When you go their and you find your dish, you'll understand

4.description: We went to the Clybourn location. Holy cow. If I could give them an extra half star, I would. I come from Miami and spent most of my life eating this type of food. It's the closest taste to home I have tried in Chicago.

6.description: This is the Original 90 Miles to Cuba @ 3101 N Clybourn Avenue (hint it's actually a little further then 90 miles to Cuba). It's a really cool tiny little restaurant on a triangular corner bordered by Elston, Oakley & Barry.  The decor both on the outside & inside are reminiscent of Cuban restaurants.  The dining inside is somewhat limited with NO tables & about 10 bar stools.  The walls on the inside are wallpapered with newspaper clippings from Cuban newspapers.  There is another newer & bigger "90 Miles to Cuba" @ 2540 W Armitage, but you need to experience the original one first. I ordered the Cubano Sandwich it is delicious.  The perfect blend of ham, roasted pork, Swiss cheese, pickles & mustard toasted on a piece of toasted French bread & topped off with hot sauce.  If you like things spicy it's so much better w/the hot sauce.  This also comes with banana chips.I loved the food and the atmosphere of this restaurant and will be back to try some of the other items on the menu.  I also want to check out the other location on Armitage.

22.description: Food was pretty good but some of the items are very very oily. The sandwiches are pretty good! I probably wouldn't go out of my way but if I'm in the area, it would be an option.

15.description: I've passed this cozy spot several times over the years, but only just recently got a chance to go into it. My mom sent me in for a cafe con leche, and I took this as an opportunity to scout the menu out, too.The decor is lovely, with old newspapers from Cuba and plenty of cultural art pieces. The space itself is small, but they do have an outdoor patio, which I imagine is nice for the summer. The staff seemed overwhelmed by everything going on, and the restaurant wasn't even very busy. Maybe they were understaffed. The counter person was responsible for taking orders, running food and also making all the drinks, which depending on what you get, could take a while. There seemed to be confusion as to where food was going, which sort of dragged things out a while. I imagine it might help if the staff asked their customers if they would be seated indoors or on the patio....I waited for 20+ minutes for two coffees and my shake. This was definitely more than I would like to wait, and I consider myself extremely patient. This time did give me the chance to look over the menu though, which was awkwardly placed next to the counter (making it hard for someone just walking in to really get to the menu BEFORE having to place the order). The food I did see looked delicious and reasonably priced.I would come back and try the food, but choose a time that's significantly less busy than a Saturday early afternoon....

57.description: This location has a small, quick to go or eat in option, but that doesn't take away from the awesome food! The armitage location offers more space for dining in.  I've never had a bad meal here, and I can't leave without getting a cuban espresso!!!

20.description: Holy grease ball batman. Super disappointed in this sandwich. The bread was soaked everything.

36.description: Empanadas and plantains are fantastic!  Great meal for relatively inexpensive price.  Very friendly staff.  Quick service. Cute decor.  Definitely will return.

14.description: Loved this place. Until they forgot to put my chips in my bag I politely called back and told them they forgot it the woman responded saying she didn't charge me for them which was a lie cuz I had the receipt. Make sure you check your bag before you leave because this is not the first time it's happened to me. Won't be eating here again. They one on armitage is way nicer better food and definitely better service

3.description: With all the chiropractors out there, it's hard to choose which one to spend your hard earned money on. Dr. Sarouri is genuinely interested in helping his patients heal. He is very likable!I also saw his massage therapist, Candice. She is very pleasant but I needed something with a bit more force (like deep tissue) so I opted not to try again.The office is nice, but you will hear the resident upstairs stomping around and possibly some pipes in the wall banging every so often. But, the care received at this office is good quality. Dr. Sarouri does acupuncture and it's pretty decent.  Overall, a good experience and I would recommend this office to anyone on the fence about who to choose for these services. You can't go wrong with Dr. Sarouri and his friendly staff.

1.description: Dr. Sorouri is a really knowledgeable chiropractor with a natural, holistic approach to physical and mental well being. He gave me great tips on relieving tail bone pain and of course seeing him for my weekly adjustments helps so much! I also tried acupuncture for the first time and absolutely loved it! His front staff is extremely professional and nice. The practice is very clean and comfortable and conveniently located.

2.description: The highlight of my week! I started going to Global Chiropractic about a year ago for back and foot pain. I am very happy with the service I have received and I can see great improvements. The staff is very friendly and knowledgable. I would highly recommend them if you're looking for chiropractor and massage services.

5.description: I've gone to Dr. Sorouri on two separate  occasions for a lower back and neck problem. Lower back is a long standing condition and the neck was new. I felt like the treatment I received was the simplest route to my healing. When we get injured it feels crippling on so many levels. Dr. Sorouri understands this and helped me to get to a place where I started feeling empowered and in control again, not just a victim of my body pains. The variety of therapies Global Chiropractic offers made going into the office a unique experience for me every time. I got treated with physical therapy exercises, slight traditional manipulations, acupuncture, massage and this vibrating, lite pulse therapy that just loosened up all of my muscles.  I felt immediate relief for both conditions within a couple of days and total relief of my back within 2 weeks and my neck within 3 weeks. I guess the trick is to go in as soon as the injury or pain happen. Thankfully I found Global Chiropractic and went in right away. Basically, if you need to relieve pain from your body, and need knowledgeable guidance on the best way for you to do that, Dr. Sorouri's your guy. He's kind, easy-going and very smart. The office space is cozy with beautiful local artists work featured on the walls. The staff is sweet and easy-going. Over-all great experience. Will definitely be back if the need arises.

6.description: I started seeing Dr. Sorouri for pain I had around my right elbow.  It wasn't going away and the pain started to become severe affecting my day to day routine.  I stopped hitting the gym and was starting to gain some weight, which isn't good when you're planning on getting married in a few months.  Who wants to be fat on a honeymoon? I'm a retired rugby player so I'm used to injury...So when the old rest, ice, compress and elevate didn't work, I knew I had a problem.  The pain was obviously not going away and it was actually getting worse everyday...even with the downtime form the gym!  I saw Dr. Sorouri and he did a thorough examination and determined that the pain was actually nerve pain from discs in my neck...I had an MRI and it confirmed that I had 2 herniated discs pinching and irritating the nerves giving me the pain that I had.  I had no clue that a disc injury could give you pain in your arms and was freaked out that somehow I injured it...As bad as it sounded, Dr. Sorouri's confidence in treating this kind of problem put me at ease.  He took the time to explain to me why I had the problem, how he was going to fix it and what I should do in the future to prevent it.  He made me take an ACTIVE role in my treatment and put me on a home exercise program that within a few weeks took care of the problem.  Right now I'm back to my regular routine, dropped 11 pounds and 100% PAIN-FREE!  He and the others that work in the office are upbeat, positive and professional. They make you feel like you're the only patient they treat.  I highly recommend this office!

7.description: Global does great work. Dr. Mehran Sorouri is a caring medical professional. He has a strong background in medicine and medical treatments. He takes time to know the patients personally, in addition to their medical history, to provide the best care. The staff and therapists are very detailed and complete. The technology and equipment used during therapy are great.

8.description: I have been to several Chiropractors in the past.  One who claimed I was "too sensitive" to recieve his treatments.  I heard about Dr. Mehran Sorouri through my hair stylist who also has been treated by him.  I have numbness in my arms and neck pain.  Dr. Sorouri understood that I was sensitive because I'm in pain.  He took the time to examin me and gave me some exercises to do at home that actually worked for me!  He is very gentle and has not hurt me. He has a great chairside manner and you can tell he loves what he does.  Anyone looking for a great chiropractic experience should go to Dr. Sorouri.  He takes my insurance and has good hours.  You can park on the side streets for free.  He also has a very nice staff!

9.description: Dr. Mehran Sorouri has changed my life.  That is not an over dramatization.  I have suffered from Migraines for many years and have tried many, many treatments unsuccessfully.  On a recommendation from a friend and colleague, I tried Global Chiropractic.  Having never been to a chiropractor before, I didn't know what to expect.  The first session included an extremely thorough discussion with Dr. Sorouri about my medical history, lifestyle, etc.  Followed by some very deep tissue work, some adjustments and stretching and finally acupuncture. He also made a couple of recommendations of things I could do at home.   He is very well educated and combines the different methods he is trained in for the most effective customized treatment. I am absolutely delighted that after 6 visits (within a two week period) I have not had a headache since I started going (unbelievable) and haven't had to go back. If I did have any reason to seek additional treatment though, I would call Amy, the very friendly, professional receptionist and make an appointment right  away.

0.description: Global is the "Gold Standard" for integrative care. I say that after seeing at least 6 different chiropractors in the last 15 years for various reasons. Dr Sorouri was very thorough and knowledgeable. He gave me his undivided attention and worked on me for a solid 30 minutes.  I loved the fact that clinic also offers massage therapy. Unfortunately, i only got a 60 mins..I really wanted a 90 mins session buy the therapist was booked up. Jennifer is phenomenal and very experienced. She did a combination of deep tissue and craniosacral therapy on me and I was a new man. I'm very thankful to the Global team. Looking forward to my next visit!

4.description: I'm not one to write reviews, but when someone/some business has something wonderful to offer, I take the time!Dr. Sorouri is sincere, motivated and loves what he does. That being said, with just 3 visits, I feel such a difference in my neck, shoulders, sinuses and jaw pain. Between adjustments, massage and acupuncture, I can honestly say my pain has subsided. My mobility is greater given the exercises he provided me with as well. Kudos to Dr. Sorouri.Having never seen a chiropractor before, I'm sold.

3.description: This Subway is a sneaky bitch.Seriously.To personify, this Subway is that easy, slutty, thin and moderately attractive girl that you assume you can easily bone without repercussions.  However, post-bone you find out that:1) She lied about "Yea, I get AIDS tested every 3 months!"2) She poked a hole in the condom.You're fucked.There is a new promotion currently at Subway.  After 5 p.m. you can get any sub, minus the couple premium subs, for $5.00 as long as you buy at least 2 subs.  I got 2 subs.  I decided that I wanted to add what the signs all over the store call "a combo" for $2.00.  This means I grab a small soda and a bag of chips.  Well, while the worker is prepping my sub I take the initiative and grab my chips, open them and start munching, and then quickly fill my soda.  I get to the register and am charged just shy of $15.00.  You do the math.  Over charged $2.00+.Apparently the combo does not apply with the new promotion.  However, there is NO fine print saying this.  The signs say "Add chips and drink to your sub for $2.00".  For some Subways it's $2.20.I was pissed.  I jumped over the counter and grabbed the Indian cashier by his scruffy neck and pulled him within scant centimeters of my face, and then I bit his fucking nose off.I'm currently wanted for attempted murder.  Worth it.Cheeers.

1.description: I love this place cause its open 24 hours, the evening and night staff are awesome. I'm taking off two stars cause you need to watch out for this lady with a ponytail who works the early AM shift cause she tries to overcharge.

2.description: I like Subway for fast food eating with my kids. It doesn't make me feel so guilty since we all get a bit of vegetables in. My problem with this place is the service. The people behind the counter are rude and have absolutely no people skills. Last time I was in here was about 5 years ago and today's visit will keep me away for another 5.

0.description: Likes: More vegetarian options than other places (veggie patty or falafel), seems clean, friendly service when it's not busy.Dislikes: Tiny parking lot that is often full and how busy it gets during lunchtime due to it's proximity to Lane Tech.If you can go during off-peak times AND find a place to park, then it's worth it.

4.description: I go to this Subway a lot and am usually pleased with what I get.But this past time I went here, I was not pleased at all!It was the worst experience ever because the service was terrible.The women worker, I'm afraid I didnt get her name, who served us was extremely rude.It was after swimming with my friends that we went here.We were so happy that we came here because we were being healthy.Half of us wanted to go to McDonald's! : PAnyway, we were in Subway and the women asked us"Do you want sandwichs?"We said yes, of course, and started joking around thinking "What else would we get here?"Well, the woman took it offensively so we apologized but we could see she wasn't too happy.So as she was making our sandwichs she asked us if we wanted them toasted.One of my friends said to the woman that she didn't want her sandwich toasted,but then quickly changed her mind and decided she did.The woman worker grunted and threw her sandwich on the pan to be put in the toaster oven.Then another customer walked in the door.The woman worker started putting the different ingredients on the sandwichs of ours. When she got my sandwich and I started to tell her my choice of veggies, she blurted "Hurry Up" to me.Sooooo Rude! I was not happy at all! I will only go here in emergency.This was a horrible experience.Just remember when you come here:Sandwichs=Good                Service=BadMaybe we should've gone to McDonald's!!!

58.description: A Dive Bar with character.  This is exactly what we're talking about.  Beer selection:  Strong.  Enjoyed a Brekenridge Vanilla Porter on tap as well as a Sierra Nevada Celebration Ale in bottle.  Bartender on this early Saturday night was Luz.  She's one of the proprietors and was very friendly and provided some excellent conversation.The backstory is that my date knows one of the owners very well.  She says hello to Luz, who she hasn't seen in years and knows a bit also.  Turns out, some of the couches were originally my date's and donated many years ago!  Well, this only added to the fun of it all.  Ah, and let's not forget they actually have an old Gallaga game in there.  Gallaga.  Go figure. You could spend hours in this place looking at all of the different memorabilia posted all over the walls, and the nick knacks  on the shelves among the beer selections.As others have said, don't go there for the ball game.  It's a place to go and chill,  have a good quiet conversation among friends.  It's a cash only bar, so keep that in mind.  But don't worry, the drinks are inexpensive.

56.description: Something off of the Sundance Channel. That's what I thought when I first visited this dark, 80's retro low-key bar, seemingly in the middle of nowhere.  It's so easy to drive or walk right by this humble little bar and that's really a shame if you don't get to experience this gem.After partying near boystown, a good friend introduced me to this cute little cash-only bar just a few doors east of Western on Belmont.  We were warmly greeted by Luz, who went ouf her way to help us pick special beers. And make NO mistake about it, it's all about the quality beer selection on draught and in bottles.  They don't serve food but encourage you to bring your own or have it delivered to the bar.  Sometimes the "Tamale Guy" shows up. They're like the everyday person's version of Hopleaf Bar.  The prices are very affordable here and on some nights you have to keep your mouth closed when there's a live band playing, because people want to hear the music... not your puffed up convo. Take it outside!

29.description: "Hungry...Brain...."That sounds like zombie dialogue to me. But it's not the theme of this bar. Maybe a hungry brain; one that craves knowledge or culture. While this isn't a high brow salon, this dive bar does host a lot of eclectic events from shows, to open mics, to readings and has a lot of character. It's quite dark illuminated by different colored strings of Christmas lights, candles, and a few interesting lamps. A hodge podge of old or shabby chic furniture. Lots of posters of local events and entertainment on walls. An intriguing collection of art that each invite a closer look. And a Galaga/Pac Man machine in the front by the stage (and most of the time seating area) and an Arachnoid machine in the back. All of this doesn't seem insincere or self consciously odd but inviting. Like we were in a true blue place.They have a neat beer list and the bartender was a pip. The jukebox is fantastic with a great selection of classic rock, Motown, 90's alternative, new music, movie soundtracks. We found the atmosphere, music, and games a delight. Now. Much ado has been made about the cozy couches. On the stage there's 2 couches, a sturdy arm chair, a coffee table, and a stool. These couches either are different than the ones mentioned in other reviews or I'm descended from the Princess and the Pea because one couch is goofy. It's like one enormous mushy pillow. We sat in it and instantly sank to the center swallowed up by the marshmallow couch; our asses were 'bout 4 inchs from the floor. The other red velvet one was better but had a couple wonky springs. The ID checker guy who also clears tables was downer. We left a beer and glass of water on a stool by us and our coats. He started taking them and I said we weren't done and he was curt.The crowd is mixed you'll see big groups and even a guy reading a book alone with a Guinness at a table. A tamale guy came. Fun, chill place."Hungry Brain!" - no zombie.

42.description: Great atmosphere and a good bar but it's cash only.It's a great bar to have a conversation with friends on a crowded night.It also has one of the best jukeboxes in Chicago.

23.description: About as solid as a dive bar can get. Clean enough (for a dive) with solid service and a decent selection. Plenty of seating, lots of options, cash only.

47.description: Love this place! The staff behind the bar are nice and laid back. The decor and furniture is comfy and eclectic. I didn't think it was possible to have a dive bar with personality, but they nailed it.

8.description: Oh, Hungry Brain, I do have feelings for you. Mixed, just like the company and drinks I enjoyed. Many a night I had caroused with people I loved, some of them gone now, within your the confines of your dimly lit warmth. You weren't perfect, but I sure as hell wasn't either, and who is? Now you've decided to leave us too. I hate change, but I know it is inevitable. It's what happens. You're not the first beloved bar I've lost, you won't be the last. I will miss you with a woeful sigh, and without a doubt.

31.description: Sometimes you wanna go where nobody knows your name, but they're always glad you came. This place makes you feel welcome like an ex gf who's been bootycalling you for months.Strolled in here on a Tuesday night for an after dinner drink and happened upon an improv comedy night in progress.  The first guy doing his shtick was a little boring and I honestly felt could tell a funnier story about a visit to City Hall to pay my parking tickets, but the talent got progressively better.  Your night isn't a total waste if you can have some good brews and laugh at lesbian's account of her "first kiss" and her mission to get laid and getting (in her own words) some "Puss" for the first time in college.  A hetero man can relate!The decor is eclectic to say the least.  Imagine you have one Saturday afternoon and only $75 to furnish your bar, what do you do?  You hit up every garage sale you can and pick up mismatched couches, tables, and chairs..somehow it all comes together nicely and The Brain has a nice homey feel like drinking in your buddy's basement circa 1970.I've been here twice and if you have an affinity for dive bars, add this one to the top of your list!

34.description: Some odd furniture to say the least. Decent bar.

16.description: You probably have to live here and go in a lot to appreciate it.  We made a trek from Pilson to see a friend, no signage on the outside just a fairly east european facade, minimal inside, dark, functional chairs and tables, 1 sofa.  I guess I expected a few more.  Pacman machine winking in the background, cheap drinks and friendly bar staff.  Pretty empty on a Saturday night at 9.00pm but feels like more of a last drink late night spot.

13.description: O Hungry Brain! If only you had served fish...

11.description: "Hungry...Brain...."That sounds like zombie dialogue to me. But it's not the theme of this bar. Maybe a hungry brain; one that craves knowledge or culture. While this isn't a high brow salon, this dive bar does host a lot of eclectic events from shows, to open mics, to readings and has a lot of character. It's quite dark illuminated by different colored strings of Christmas lights, candles, and a few interesting lamps. A hodge podge of old or shabby chic furniture. Lots of posters of local events and entertainment on walls. An intriguing collection of art that each invite a closer look. And a Galaga/Pac Man machine in the front by the stage (and most of the time seating area) and an Arachnoid machine in the back. All of this doesn't seem insincere or self consciously odd but inviting. Like we were in a true blue place.They have a neat beer list and the bartender was a pip. The jukebox is fantastic with a great selection of classic rock, Motown, 90's alternative, new music, movie soundtracks. We found the atmosphere, music, and games a delight. Now. Much ado has been made about the cozy couches. On the stage there's 2 couches, a sturdy arm chair, a coffee table, and a stool. These couches either are different than the ones mentioned in other reviews or I'm descended from the Princess and the Pea because one couch is goofy. It's like one enormous mushy pillow. We sat in it and instantly sank to the center swallowed up by the marshmallow couch; our asses were 'bout 4 inchs from the floor. The other red velvet one was better but had a couple wonky springs. The ID checker guy who also clears tables was downer. We left a beer and glass of water on a stool by us and our coats. He started taking them and I said we weren't done and he was curt.The crowd is mixed you'll see big groups and even a guy reading a book alone with a Guinness at a table. A tamale guy came. Fun, chill place."Hungry Brain!" - no zombie.

39.description: Ok very cool atmosphere (dark, candlelit tables), but I came on a Friday night with a few friends and the ratio was terrible.  Probably 15 guys and 3 girls.  Overrated.

37.description: I've been going here 15 years since I lived in Roscoe Village.  Friendly bartenders, dark, convivial, near the lowest prices in town, interesting clientele,  great bookings including a long running jazz series.  good place to hang with friends and make new ones.  Live in LA now, but I get back to Chicago a few times a year and Always make sure to have a few drinks here.

0.description: Coat hooks: No. Welcome Back, Hungry Brain! Get some coat hooks.

38.description: I came here for Two Cookie Minimum's Industry Night. As far as I was concerned, the drinks/venue were ancillary to hearing local writers and publishers expound on their craft, and read their works aloud, but I decided to step outside of my comfort zone and come here, making the train-to-bus transfer necessary to do so. The setup was not daunting at all and I'm pleased that the ambiance read cozy and careworn versus dark and forbidding. The drink selections are reasonable and the bar staff friendly, which is all that I ask out of my establishments. I most likely won't seek out this establishment for its own sake but will definitely make it a point to investigate future industry nights here as they arise.

51.description: I love dive bars, and this one is no exception. Non-pretentious, cash only, and just a little out of the way. The mismatched tables/chairs remind you of your grandparent's basement. Sweet cider on tap and good music. And who should appear last night but the tamale guy himself.I wish DC had a tamale guy.

27.description: I love it here.  One of the best bars in the city.  Want a bar where you can go with your friends, catch up, and enjoy the jukebox?  Check out the Brain.  Or maybe you want to watch a man in full clown attire perform his most recent spoken word art project.  Check out the Brain.  No matter what, you'll find a chair or stool at a cool bar with excellent (and inexpensive!) drinks, fun vibe, and an interesting and mixed crowd.  The tamale guy rolls in around 10.  There's still a bit of the old Roscoe Village that comes here, artists and musicians mixing with the new moneyed crowd.  But the Brain is a sort of neutral ground, a place where all can come and have a great time.

32.description: My new neighborhood bar, and I couldn't be happier. Great vibe, awesome bartenders, great Chicago beers on tap for only $4.50, so glad this place is literally across the street. Because it's so cool it can occasionally get over hipsterfied. But hey, fuck 'em!

54.description: I've only been a couple times to see friends of mine perform, but this is a very cool little venue for local, independent artists.  They have a cool atmosphere and good list of performers on their calendar...what else could you ask for?

48.description: I had a great time here. I was worried I was venturing into a "too cool" hipster enclave (I'm not a hipster), but the place was actually very welcoming and relaxed - a really comfortable bar, hipsterish without being excluding. They were hosting a monthly revue (music, spoken word, comedy, etc.) the night I showed up. The house band "Good Evening" was very good - I was impressed (goodeveningmusic.com), a folk/pop sound. Another highlight was a crazy, gusto-filled reading of a sci-fi story by a guy in a pinstripe suit. The jukebox is really good, too. I'd definitely go back again.

44.description: Im not really a fan of dive bars, but eclectic/bizarre/craft beer dive bars?? SOLD!I came here last week with a friend and was immediately drawn to all the crazy shit on the walls. Random eclectic artwork, craft beer signage, toys, couch sections, 1970's tables, and brain-affiliated items behind the bar really add to the craziness that is Hungry Brain. I had a bells two hearted and my friend had an original sin. At $4.50 for each drink, the pricing cant be beat, especially in Chicago. A couch area to relax and chat it up, good music playing on the jukebox, christmas lights, comfy bar stools, and a nice dark setting all tie in to make this a great go-to dive to close out the night. However, don't come here if you are hungry for brains bc they don't serve any food (as far as i know - i was pretty wasted). All in all, if you are a fan of craft beer like me, and dont want to overpay like most places in Chicago, Hungry Brain is the place. It just screams unpretentious =)

24.description: Well I was neither hungry nor angry when I went there; actually, I was simply coaxed by friends I had gone to visit in Chicago. It is a chill place with a rather mixed crowd, so regardless of which social group you belong to, you are bound to feel comfortable.On entry I spotted the Pacman machine close to the stage, rushed to it with an aim of beating the prevailing high score. But bah!!, I failed miserably. My consolation target the jukebox wasted my 10, only to be told by some cutie that it accepted 5's and 1's only. However the jukebox has a variety of good music, so regardless of your genre of choice you are bound to find something that suits you on it.Well we hit the couch with my newfound friend, hit off with small talk. The seats were rather comfortable. In addition, gladly the amiable bar attendants did not have me waiting when I sought drinks from them. Talking of drinks, the thing I liked about this place are the really affordable drinks. Plus there is the Tamale guy, he popped in at around 10.

7.description: Closed at the end of business on December 31st. RIP forever, Hungry Brain. Hopefully the bartenders here end up at other bars, as well!

49.description: I was told, long before I saw it , that the Hungry Brain is possibly one of the coolest dive bars in the world and to prove the point the man who told me so informed me that almost every night there is a dude who stops by on his way home from work and has a drink, then he goes back home and puts on a Batman outfit and comes BACK to the bar, where he then has two or three more drinks and then goes home. I had to see this place - preferably wearing a Cinderella costume or maybe Cruella De Ville, hadn't decided. But Jumpin' Jimmeny  Catfish when I finally went there, Hungry Brain did not disappoint, dim, random, intellectual AND seedy - how does it get better than that? Add to it a decent selection of good (if not great)scotches at a low, low (cash only) price and well... I was in heaven. Always good music on the juke box, or random performing artists, unique plays, music, ahhhh it is a cornucopia of comfy weirdness that I just fell in love with. Sadly I live in River North , so I don't get there as often as I would like and while there are plenty of cool and pretentious bars in my neck o the woods - trust me there are NO Hungry Brains.... BTW - I did ask the Bartender about Batman and completely non plussed he said oh yeah, that guy, its cool ( as in its no big thing). I said did you ever ask him why he does that? He said why would I? none of my business. Now THAT's cool.

40.description: Came here for a joint birthday party and I had a pretty good impression, but everyone hyped this place up way too much for me so I think my expectations were a bit high. Hungry Brain itself feels like a friend's basement hangout spot - cozy, dark, and friendly. Everyone here was cordial, and drink prices are relatively cheap compared to other bars in Chicago. They have a killer jukebox machine, and it was a lot of fun looking through the records they have.However, this place is in a pretty inconvenient spot that isn't around a lot of "foot traffic" so it's hard to get to conveniently if you don't bike or have a car. There is also not a lot around these parts, so if you wanted to get here from another place or go to someplace else from the Brain, you'd have to rely on public transit or catch a cab (if you don't have a bike).  The Belmont bus drops you off right in front of the bar, but I'd have to transfer from another bus to the Belmont bus to get to this place. Arg! (Yes, I am complaining about this, but it's my review so I can complain all I want!) With that said, I had a good time and saw many good friends.  The crowd that comes here is a bit older, like around late 20s - mid 30s.  Just not the kind of atmosphere where you can rage and stuff like that, but definitely a cozy spot for a chill evening with close friends. I think I want to come back on a weekday and see what it's like.

53.description: A bit like drinking in your crazy uncle's rec room, if said crazy uncle hasn't updated it since the 1970's, this place is exactly what a dive bar should be:  low lighting, cheap drinks, odd decorations scattered around the walls, and great people watching.  What sets it apart:  it's clean - seriously, and has way more (good) beers on tap than you would expect.  A bit of a trek to get to, I've never had a bad time when I go.

30.description: Top five in the city(IMO) for chilling with peeps and drinking good beer from the typical "cash only" b.s. in the city of Chicago. Reasons I enjoy this place? Good beer, cheap prices, chill atmosphere, comfy couches(please no bed bugs), and a GREAT Jukebox which is a rarity it seems these days as it feels like most bars let the bartenders choose the music or DJ the whole night through.Enjoy Suckas'!!!

46.description: Nice layout & atmosphere.  Nice selection of drinks.

1.description: This is a love note, not a review.2015 was coming to a close and I spotted the bartender. RA!!! It was her first night on the job and she had on these high-waisted jeans. RA!! Girl, you don't need to make an old fashioned because you are all the sugar I need. RA!! No, but seriously, where is my cocktail? If you read this, girl of my dreams, I want to hold your hand. 2016 is already a success because I know you're out there for me. RA!!

55.description: I might have been the oldest dude in the place, but I can pull it off cause I'm a cool dude in a loose mood.  A quirky, hipster joint with vintage furniture and lighting. Quite comfortable, living room feel.  It does have entertainment venues. I was recently there observing a Lisa DeRosia and Lush Budget performance.  Don't wear coordinated outfits in this place, cause that's a giveaway that yer non-Scottish.  I don't know if it was part of the theme last night, or if the Skipper from Gilligan's Island look is all the rage these days as I seem to have spied an inordinate amount of Captains caps and Hawaiin shirts in the audience.  But, I do know that if you have the compunction to wear a Russian Combat Helmet in public with Chuck Taylor knock offs you certainly can pull it off here.  All serious, though, it's a great place. $4.00 for the great tap beers and yer not limited to the Bud and Miller. No one bothers you here, and you are quick to blend into the wallpaper once you sit in one of the comfy Sofas or chairs. Even these Bohemian Hipsters are hooked on the cells and texting, so feel free to imbibe in your electronic addiction here.It's located just down the street from Chicago PD's Area 5, so if you get locked up your buddies can literally bond you right out...but, no worries with that, the BRAIN ain't seedy, and dangerous at all.  It's an intellectual crowd, and friendly.  They kept calling me SIR, and I kept turning around to see if my father was there.   I'm definitely going back often.

9.description: With a name like "Hungry Brain", you'd think that they'd cater to the likes of the undead, or the Walking Dead, you know, ZOMBIES.Not true!!! Everyone who was there when I stumbled there on a recent Saturday night was very much alive, with their very human activities of breathing in air and blood coursing through their veins. At least, I assumed that they were, I didn't get close enough to anyone to feel them breathe on me or check their pulses. Anyways, I loved this dive bar which was suggested by a friend. It was chill, yet had plenty of energy on a Saturday night, but not too loud or crazy, perfect for divin' with friends. And they had couches! So comfortable and awesome to sit on a couch, chatting with friends. But be warned that the couches are from the 60s and 70s, so you might fall into one of them and not get out because they're broken, but hey, I'm not complaining!Jukebox - checkComfortable seating - checkSweet lighting - checkMeet me there next Saturday night, friends?

26.description: One day after work some of my colleagues asked me if I wanted to go with them to the Hungry - Brain. Althought I did n't have the mood for drinks, I went anyway. The moment I stepped in it was 80s all over again. The decor, the junkbox and service, everything was there to make me feel at home. That place had so many memories from my childhood: the music my parents were listening to when I was young, the pictures and even the people"s attitudes.Really liked it, not to mention that the beer is just refreshing. I went there just to have a drink and I got out of at 2am. The bartender nearly kicked us out so to speak. I will defenitely go back some day. Thanks Hungry-Brain !!!

25.description: Oh, this place is so hipster cool.  I love it.

12.description: This is the best bar I have ever been to. Let me share a tale with you:I originally saw the bar on Yelp while wandering around Belmont on a Friday night, and with the great reviews and single dollar sign and the great name decided to make it the last place I'd go for the night. First, I wandered past the place two or three times, since there's not really a sign or anything to tell you where it is. I finally took a look through the window on the door, and could barely make out the figure of people inside, since (at least in my imagination, I'll have to go back and make sure) the window was too grimy to properly see through. Finally walk in, and the place smells like the cool kid you knew in high school's basement. There is a jukebox the runs LASER DISKS, which I haven't seen in like a decade. There is absolutely insane art on the walls, a lot of which features anthropomorphic brains. I sit down at the bar, and get a pint of 5$ Great Lakes (and they had equally good beers for cheaper I think!). The bartender was a really friendly guy, and fills the glasses up absolutely to the rim and overflowing (none of that bullsh*t where they give you a half full glass and charge full price!). There were like 10 other people in the bar at the time, and it was the perfect volume for having a conversation. Then the guy comes over. This dude just sits down next to me and kind of awkwardly strikes up a conversation. I quickly gather he's heavily intoxicated, but is generally really friendly (although does say a few offensive things that would have made me think twice about him if he wasn't otherwise a merry guy). He proceeds to tell his life story (including his time in prison, coming to Chicago and starting a consulting gig, in true "Fear and Loathing" style his crazy night with his attorney that night, and how he met his girilfriend). He also apparently knows everyone else in the bar, and (once again mildly offensively) calls one over who seems to be a bit less amused with his condition. He buys everyone shots, throws up a bit, and zips back and forth for the rest of the evening. If anyone has seen the Miyazaki movie "Spirited Away" and remembers how that guy was the "River Spirit", this guy right here was the "Dive Bar Spirit". He truely made my evening from kinda meh to absolutely incredible. Anyway, that is the kind of place the Hungry Brain is, and I can't wait to go back. This is fantastic bar, great divey atmosphere/charm, great/cheap beer, and great company. Go here, you won't regret it.

59.description: if this was just a bar, i would make the trek just for people watching the clientele.  keep in mind that this is not a good pre-gaming location or a destination for the height of the night.   -- if you come here, you intend to sit and chat and sit and chat. but this is not just a bar!  want to hear a real secret ?  go on weeknights around 9 pm to listen to a live recording of "you, me, them, everybody."  YMTE is a podcast focusing on chicago culture (which just means it's a talk show with comedians and musicians from the chicago area).  the show is always funny, the music is usually bizarre, and the drinks are cheap. youmethemeverybody.com/e…  for the schedule of events. bring cash for beer and the jukebox.

21.description: Very cool spot. Delightfully divey. Good prices and beer selection. Very laid-back vibe. It's very dark, but a great spot for live music and hanging out.

17.description: Don't blink while you're going down Belmont looking for this place, or you'll miss it. With it's very dim lighting and random assortment of furniture, The Hungry Brain feels more like a lounge than a dive bar, in a good way. Unlike most dive bars, they have a nice beer list, but with typical Lakeview prices.  The music selection on the jukebox is far from typical, and the Pacman/Galaga game provides added entertainment. If you're looking for something off the beaten path with a laidback atmosphere, then check out this bar. My only complaint about The Hungry brain is that they're cash only; so be sure to stop an ATM before arriving.

10.description: Hungry Brain is one of the higher rated bars in Chicago for a number of reasons:- Quality craft beer selections, including some Three Floyd's beers you don't see very often.- Said quality craft beers are also silly cheap.  Last time I was there they had Dogfish Head for 4 bucks.  I almost thought it was an error.- Solid juke box.The location is off the beaten path, but that's also a good thing because you don't have an overly crowded place.  Do your best to visit this dive bar.  It's worth the effort.120/365

5.description: Great spot open again for real. Good atmosphere, reasonable drinks, and live jazz Sunday night. Don't pass up this neighborhood gem.

3.description: One of Chicago's finest dive bars.  Great beer selection, and while I haven't experienced it first hand, they have great live music.

35.description: A cute little dive bar that doesn't try to be more than it is.... cheap drinks, cozy seats, and a friendly bartender - win!

19.description: Well I was neither hungry nor angry when I went there; actually, I was simply coaxed by friends I had gone to visit in Chicago. It is a chill place with a rather mixed crowd, so regardless of which social group you belong to, you are bound to feel comfortable.On entry I spotted the Pacman machine close to the stage, rushed to it with an aim of beating the prevailing high score. But bah!!, I failed miserably. My consolation target the jukebox wasted my 10, only to be told by some cutie that it accepted 5's and 1's only. However the jukebox has a variety of good music, so regardless of your genre of choice you are bound to find something that suits you on it.Well we hit the couch with my newfound friend, hit off with small talk. The seats were rather comfortable. In addition, gladly the amiable bar attendants did not have me waiting when I sought drinks from them. Talking of drinks, the thing I liked about this place are the really affordable drinks. Plus there is the Tamale guy, he popped in at around 10.

28.description: Literally the closest bar to my home, and yes, that was a selling point of the place.Every bartender is a treat. I would live on the back porch in the summer if I had the chance.I love you, Hungry Brain.

45.description: Went here on a Saturday night and this is my kind of bar. A nice young, somewhat subdued crowd. We had a group of 8 to 10 and we were able to put a couple of tables together and have conversations. Nobody had to yell over music or any drunk bimbos. There were a bunch of drink specials. Nothing too amazing, but it was very reasonably priced. The bartender was super nice. She would also remember what you ordered and make recommendations based on your previous drink. There are some retro videogames, which is cool once you get a buzz going. I am not a bar guy at all and I really enjoyed my time in this place.

33.description: I love this place. I recently moved to Roscoe Village and this place is across the street from me. It's a perfect dive bar. The arrangement of mismatch furniture and vintage toys is cozy and whimsical. The jukebox is great. The drinks are the perfect price. Bartenders are really nice too.There was a really bad experience on Sunday where I got scoffed at by a band member because I didn't have any cash on me and he wanted a 'suggested donation' of 5 dollars, even though my friend donated 4.If you wanted a cover, then make there be a cover. I didn't come to see your band play, I just wanted some drinks.

43.description: I love this place - from their wonky assortment of furniture right down to their $4.50 craft beers (decent selection I may add).Jukebox has a nice selection of classic and indie tunes.  But watch it - it only takes ones and fives.  Don't even dream of putting a ten in there.  You're not getting anymore plays than you would for a fiver, but you're losing your full ten spot.  Believe that.  (Special thanks to the bartender who gave us five bucks to make up for our jukebox loss)My favorite Roscoe Village dive bar - and really my favorite Roscoe Village bar in general.

2.description: I am such a fan of this place. The atmosphere is always so welcoming and fun. The food and background music makes you feel at ease. Definitely will be a returning customer.

18.description: dope.

41.description: Good crowds, good music. Cash only bar, but the prices are reasonable. The atmosphere is especially good - casual with lots of places to sit.They have weird hours, so make sure they're open before you head over.

52.description: Wow - haven't been to a good old dive like this in quite some time!  Yes, the Bulls happened to be playing in a playoff game the night we went, but the place was completely empty.  We walked in to this very dimly lit big open bar to find lots of couches, loungy chairs, and old school booths, ordered a few beers and rotated our seating choice three times, just for the hell of it.  Good juke box, chill vibe, nice bartender, more unique than most bars - a good option for a bar you can actually converse with and hear your companions.

50.description: Great place, great staff, reasonable prices, love the ambiance and clientele

4.description: Bar had it all. Great drafts, Music, Fiction Readings. Comfy seating. Small outdoor areas. BYOF policy. It is truly sorely missed.

6.description: I am so glad this place is back, I just found out! This is one of Chicago's #1 dive bars. Very cool atmosphere, calm and laid back for a drink on a weekday. Bartenders are great. I have also seen some very cool live performances here - both music and sketch/visual art performance pieces. I am also told they have jazz on Sundays which I will have to check out. If you are in the neighborhood, check this place out. But' don't tell anyone, it's still a relatively good kept secret.

22.description: When I first moved into the neighborhood 3 years ago, and a door down from this seemingly closed or condemned building, I was surprised to see some theatre folk coming in and out of the place.  One night I decided to venture in and before you know it I was hooked.  No tv's and a nice little back patio for the summer.  Great selection of music in the jutebox.I love the mismatched furniture and funky decor.  Large armchairs and a Mrs. Pacman arcade game in the corner.One of the only bars I feel comfortable going alone or with a group of friends.Luz  is my fave bartender, but every bartender there is great and always friendly. Love this place and will keep going back to hear stories about the neighborhood.

15.description: Chilling on overstuffed couches in dimly lit funky rooms drinking affordable beer and playing the occasional round of Galaga - with the occasional hang-out in a relaxed back yard - is the ideal life and it's what Hungry Brain brings to the table.  They always have a couple of good local beers on tap and friendly bar tenders to help you out.  The jukebox is outstanding.  The collection of brain-themed putty toys behind the bar blows the competition out of the water.  Did I mention the Kate Bush clock?  But seriously, they got a good thing going here.  Jazz bands play here regularly on Sundays but I haven't been yet.  I did however have the pleasure to see Two Cookie Minimum, a presentation of zine work in Chicago that is hosted here.  My favorite bar in Chicago.

57.description: This bar is dark and pretty weird looking. It is pretty popular though and has a following. I stayed there briefly and din't care for this place. The service was slow and the bartender seemed disinterested. There were too many dudes with beards in this place. There are many beers to choose from,but that is about the only highlight of this place. Their live music seems to be very unknown abd obscure bands. The bathrooms were dirty. This place is not as great as some hipster wanabees may have you think.

20.description: Don't blink while you're going down Belmont looking for this place, or you'll miss it. With it's very dim lighting and random assortment of furniture, The Hungry Brain feels more like a lounge than a dive bar, in a good way. Unlike most dive bars, they have a nice beer list, but with typical Lakeview prices.  The music selection on the jukebox is far from typical, and the Pacman/Galaga game provides added entertainment. If you're looking for something off the beaten path with a laidback atmosphere, then check out this bar. My only complaint about The Hungry brain is that they're cash only; so be sure to stop an ATM before arriving.

36.description: AMAZING juke box, good vibe, good cheap drinks.one of the best dive bars in the city.

14.description: This is my boyfriend and his friend's favorite bar -- so of course every time I have been in Chicago, we go here.  It's known to frequenters as 'The Brain'  It's a dive bar that reminds me a lot of my favorite dive bars back home in Seattle.  It has never been crowded -- which I find to be a lot of places in Chicago.  Low lights -- I think this Christmas lights might be the only thing keeping the place lit?   They also have random things on the walls and shelves, which is a better thing to keep your eyes occupied than a blaring television, which they don't have, thank god.  They don't accept cards here but there is an ATM.  I am very ignorant when it comes to beer outside of the west coast -- but I have always been pleased with what they have on draft.  Both my boyfriend and the bartender have made excellent reccomendations to accomadate my PNW (Pacific Northwest) tastebuds.    I'm not much of a hard A person -- but they seem to have a decent selection of stuff.  The staff has always been very friendly (I am assuming it's because the people I was with frequent the Brain).  It is never too loud so you can carry on a conversation with not only the person next to you, but the person two seats down from you.

28.description: Great place to study! *They have an outdoor patio in front of the shop*It's quiet inside*Drinks are awesome (tried 3 so far: iced chai, black cherry iced tea, and the honey nut latte)*Staff is very outgoing and friendly*The owner is really nice*Located in a "hip" neighborhood (Roscoe Village)and the list goes on and on...I'm really happy that a friend of mine told me about this place. I even ditched my old study spot and decided this one was a better fit for me. Hasta mañana, HCB!

1.description: I want to start by saying I love and support local small businesses.  Went here on a Sunday morning recently and got a chai tea latte and a Manhattan bagel.  The egg was not fresh, I think it was microwave from a pre-made egg or something and some general ham that tasted like it came from the delivery section at Marianos..and not the fresh deli section.  The bagel was okay, but nothing memorable.  The combo of egg, ham, and the bagel though was nice for a quick morning breakfast.  The chai tea latte was okay, but not freshly made, I think it came from concentrate, based on how fast it was made.  The place is small and cozy and with the music, makes it smell like a coffee shop and sound like an Abercrombie and Fitch.  The service was also terrible.  The person behind the counter acted like she wanted to be anywhere but work.  Oh well, I might go back for a coffee, but won't stick around and or order food.

39.description: Great coffee.  Very friendly.  Excellent location!

9.description: If you're in Roscoe Village and you're heading up the street to get some thrifting done Village Discount, stop by Hero. The caffeine served me well in my deep plunge into the depths of preowned clothing.Some notable things:1. They have a donut with a strip of bacon on top????2. I usually don't like iced coffee, but I was all about theirs. 4. Cute little shop in a nice location.3. Service was fast and personable. Barista did kinda make fun of us for smelling like patchouli (hey, my band was touring, we get limited showers), but I probably would have made fun of us too.Will be back next time I'm around Roscoe!

29.description: So glad to have something with organic fresh options that's not starbucks. Places like this help preserve the small "village" charm of Roscoe

23.description: Order a cappuccino. Was too milky, not frothy and lacking body. Probably because it was afternoon. And as all true Italians know, no cappuccino in the afternoon.

5.description: I'm so happy this place opened so there's an alternative to regular ol' Starbucks on our street!!  Hubby loves their coffee, and I'm glad they have drinks with almond milk since I had to temporarily quit dairy.  I love the honey nut latte.  And the best thing about this place is they sell Glazed and Infused Doughnuts!!!  Now the maple bacon bar is just blocks away rather than a drive.The place itself is small and can get cramped quickly especially if there is a line.  The space is not really conducive to staying long, and the one bathroom is in the back near the kitchen.  We usually take our orders to go.

31.description: Just what the RV needed! An independent coffee shop that sells donuts and bagels! So simple yet so lacking in RV. They sell glazed and infused donuts and they sell out fast. Hoping they get a kitchen built for more food options!

25.description: Good coffee, Glazed and Infused donuts, gourmet bagel sandwich options, and a nice little patio out front.

12.description: Love this cosy neighborhood gem!  The food here is always yummy and fresh.  Delish breakfast egg & bagel sandwiches!  Great spot for lunch, too.  Pacific bird sandwich is scrummy!  Pour-over coffees have always been great, and they have really creative and tasty espresso drinks, too.  It is my favorite neighborhood spot and I go at least once a week (if not more).  Donuts are back, now, too! Yay!

37.description: This second Hero coffee bar is as good as the first one. Not a regular coffee person but the chai tea mocha just lit up my day;)

21.description: I received a "hello" and a "thank you". Things are looking up...

16.description: Finally! Great coffee shop in the middle of everything Roscoe Village. Staff is friendly and accommodating. The sandwiches are great and made to order so expect a couple minute wait. Great pour-overs and the cold brew they make is awesome. They have Glazed and Infused donuts but have a limited amount and are served on a daily basis.The only downside is they close relatively early amongst other businesses on the street.

17.description: Same song and dance as the Dearborn spot.  FIVE STARS, count em.  Roscoe Village doesn't have to settle for Charbucks any longer.  This time of year calls for alfresco coffee drinking, you're in luck b/c the patio here is perfect.  Decor is similar to the Loop decor, although I can't get a full feel for what the end product will be as they are still pulling the place together.  are you ready for this?  they are roasting their beans in house now too.  they offer a class to take about roasting, not sure what thats all about, but Im going to try to sign up.  Staff...awesome.  Sheridan and Gina...they will take care of you.  Oh and did I mention they have Glazed and Infused...enough said.  Welcome to the neighborhood Hero.

10.description: Great place to study! *They have an outdoor patio in front of the shop*It's quiet inside*Drinks are awesome (tried 3 so far: iced chai, black cherry iced tea, and the honey nut latte)*Staff is very outgoing and friendly*The owner is really nice*Located in a "hip" neighborhood (Roscoe Village)and the list goes on and on...I'm really happy that a friend of mine told me about this place. I even ditched my old study spot and decided this one was a better fit for me. Hasta mañana, HCB!

11.description: I stopped in as I wanted a switch from Starbucks and figured this would be a good alternative. I wasn't immediately greeted as the person working was chatting with another customer - which was fine but if it were busier, that wouldn't have been quite as ok with me.I thought that the coffee was ok - a bit more bitter than I like but still pretty good. I will say, though, that for an identical sized and same ingredient order to what I get at Starbucks, it was over $1 more expensive than Starbucks. For a decent taste which I didn't think was better and a more expensive coffee, I wouldn't specifically seek this spot out over other area chains (and local spots).I also thought that behind the counter wasn't organized well and seemed in disarray (stuff just piled, a charging cell phone, etc. The floor also had coffee grounds around and while this isn't totally unexpected, it seemed messy and as it was early, I wouldn't have expected that much disorder to start the day.

26.description: Same song and dance as the Dearborn spot.  FIVE STARS, count em.  Roscoe Village doesn't have to settle for Charbucks any longer.  This time of year calls for alfresco coffee drinking, you're in luck b/c the patio here is perfect.  Decor is similar to the Loop decor, although I can't get a full feel for what the end product will be as they are still pulling the place together.  are you ready for this?  they are roasting their beans in house now too.  they offer a class to take about roasting, not sure what thats all about, but Im going to try to sign up.  Staff...awesome.  Sheridan and Gina...they will take care of you.  Oh and did I mention they have Glazed and Infused...enough said.  Welcome to the neighborhood Hero.

27.description: Ok, I've been waiting for this place to open up, driving by and looking into the windows when I walk my dogs in the neighborhood.  Today I had a chance while I had to move my car to stop by to get a quick lunch.I love the space, it's cute, comfortable and welcoming.  I would love later to visit just so I can sit and enjoy the space.  The staff is friendly and helpful, there were just two people ahead of me in an empty shop so I would expect the attention, but something tells me that even when crowded I wouldn't mind waiting.  I got the cold brewed coffee which is delicious and the roast beef sandwich, I forgot what it's called on the menu.  The sandwich is yummy, just the right amount of onion and horseradish and arugula to give it that tasty greenness that complements the roast beef.There is outdoor seating here as well so I look forward to sitting outside with my pugs.  This is a welcome addition to the neighborhood which lacked a non-starbucks coffee alternative since Mojoe's had to close.  The staff was very attentive, the girl making my sandwich acknowledged the two customers who came in after me.Regarding price, I didn't find it that expensive, coffee and food are priced at what I expect prices are in this neighborhood which tends to be on the more expensive side.  I am a business owner in the area and can attest to the higher rent and more overhead that a business here has to support.  Add to this the obvious care and labor they take in making the coffee and the food here and $8 for a sandwich sounds pretty good.

35.description: Happened to walk into this place on accident. In my own neighborhood and they've been open for about 3 weeks. Just had some ice coffee for now but they sell sandwiches and really good coffee. Feels like the anti-Starbucks, so if you're into that, you'll like this.Couple of nice guys helped me. Really nice vibe and good addition to Roscoe Village.

8.description: I loooveee the lattes here, especially the honey nut latte and the lavender latte.  My favorite coffee place

0.description: This HERO is like Mighty Mouse. Small but super! There's not much in terms of space, but on the sandwich and latte front they're definitely deserved of wearing a cape. Great breakfast sandos, and for lunch the Pacific Bird is a must do. It's got incredibly fresh fixens and succulent hand cut bacon that's lives up to the nickname the candy of meats. The coffee is fresh and they sell it by the bag in case you want to brew it at home yourself. Altogether I love this place and it probably goes to show that a coffee shop prompting you to sing that song by Enrique Iglesias can never be a bad thing.

38.description: The staff are warm, knowledgeable people and are efficient without sacrificing being personable. I work across the street and have bothered Gina and Craig multiple times a day since their soft opening and have never felt rushed or in the way, even when they were slammed.The sandwiches are big without being overwhelmingly so, everything is fresh, and tastes phenomenal.I'm also a huge fan of iced coffee, especially now that it's finally warming up, and I have to say that it's the best iced coffee I have ever had. Sincerely.This coffee shop/cafe is the Hero that Roscoe Village needs. SORRY FOR THE PUN. 5 billion stars.

20.description: Finally! Great coffee shop in the middle of everything Roscoe Village. Staff is friendly and accommodating. The sandwiches are great and made to order so expect a couple minute wait. Great pour-overs and the cold brew they make is awesome. They have Glazed and Infused donuts but have a limited amount and are served on a daily basis.The only downside is they close relatively early amongst other businesses on the street.

19.description: The coffee needs improvement.  The light roast was weak.  Light roast doesn't mean that the coffee is semi-transparent.  Use more coffee or pour the water slower.  Other withdraw-the bathroom and back area.  Just a mess.  And empty fridges..... Nope.  Very nice service on the other hand.

33.description: I stopped in as I wanted a switch from Starbucks and figured this would be a good alternative. I wasn't immediately greeted as the person working was chatting with another customer - which was fine but if it were busier, that wouldn't have been quite as ok with me.I thought that the coffee was ok - a bit more bitter than I like but still pretty good. I will say, though, that for an identical sized and same ingredient order to what I get at Starbucks, it was over $1 more expensive than Starbucks. For a decent taste which I didn't think was better and a more expensive coffee, I wouldn't specifically seek this spot out over other area chains (and local spots).I also thought that behind the counter wasn't organized well and seemed in disarray (stuff just piled, a charging cell phone, etc. The floor also had coffee grounds around and while this isn't totally unexpected, it seemed messy and as it was early, I wouldn't have expected that much disorder to start the day.

2.description: Just ordered delivery and I was less than impressed. We ordered two 16 oz coffees and received one 12 oz and one 16 oz (it WAS still warm, which I was worried about)We also ordered two usual suspect bagels. They tasted pretty good; however, I ordered mine with avocado and instead of that it seems they just had extra cream cheese - such a mess.Probably won't order from here again but it was still decent!

34.description: Love this place. Finally a decent coffee in Roscoe Village!I buy their freshly roasted beans at least once a week, and they are fantastic.The staff are all really friendly, and they even have stuff to entertain kids (markers and paper).

32.description: It is great to have a delicious coffee place right near me that is locally owned! I love love love the coffee here and find the lattes very unique. I highly recommend the cardamom rose latte.This shop is still getting on its feet, so be prepared for a little wait, nothing egregious. It is just good coffee and they always brew it fresh right in front of you.

18.description: Decided to stop by after Pilates down the street. We are new to the neighborhood and trying to find a new coffee shop to love besides Sbucks was at the top of our to do list. Everyone was friendly and their lattes are soooo good! I love that they offer almond milk and decaf too. I also ordered the veggie on a jalapeño cheddar bagel...yummmmmm!

13.description: Local business with great coffee. They grind the beans for your coffee/drink on the spot -pour hot water over and let it sit. Takes maybe a few minutes longer than getting a black coffee at Starbucks but in my opinion it tastes way better . While you wait you can have a seat (one big wooden table, bar seating at the window and two two person tables) or grab a glazed and infused donut or a bagel-today they had a fig bagel with fig jam that sounded interesting! There's FREE WIFI and a cooler full of sodas, some juice and chobani yogurt. My large (16oz) coffee was 3.59 or around that. So it's pricier in that way but I do feel like it's fresh yummy coffee. They also had a honey almond nut latte I think it was called with almond milk and honey which I want to try next too! Ladies working we friendly-one a little spunky and one really sweet. Both said hi as I walked in and seemed to be well educated about their product (which I hate when the employees can't tell me about their coffee or anything) go check it out!

4.description: Great coffee. Try the honey nut latte! Not cheap here but good quality and it's nice to support a small shop like this vs the typical Starbucks. Breakfast sandwiches look good, will def be back to try more!

24.description: First time here, quiet but still busy with people. AMAZING Soy Chai tea latte. Coffee is served pour-over style and comes nice and hot! Food here is also delicious, try the Usual Suspect!

6.description: Finally tried some lunch goodies today. The sandwiches are fantastic!  I seriously love this place.  The Redline and Central Coast sandwiches were really tasty- I loved them both.  Highly recommend. The music selection here is great, the lavender latte is my favorite (iced or hot are both equally delicious), the people who work here are cool folks, and the atmosphere is perfectly adult-like for getting some work done.

22.description: Finally tried some lunch goodies today. The sandwiches are fantastic!  I seriously love this place.  The Redline and Central Coast sandwiches were really tasty- I loved them both.  Highly recommend. The music selection here is great, the lavender latte is my favorite (iced or hot are both equally delicious), the people who work here are cool folks, and the atmosphere is perfectly adult-like for getting some work done.
